headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day and welcome, to Mattel's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the conference over to Dianne Douglas. Please go ahead, ma'am.
componenttext: Good day and welcome, to Mattel's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the conference over to Dianne Douglas. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laurie. As you know, this morning, we reported Mattel's fourth quarter and full year 2009 financial results. In a few minutes, Bob Eckert, Mattel's Chairman and CEO; and Kevin Farr, Mattel's CFO will provide comments on the results and then, th
componenttext: Thank you, Laurie. As you know, this morning, we reported Mattel's fourth quarter and full year 2009 financial results. In a few minutes, Bob Eckert, Mattel's Chairman and CEO; and Kevin Farr, Mattel's CFO will provide comments on the results and then, the call will be opened for your questions.Certain statements Bob and Kevin make during the call may include forward-looking statements related to the future performance of our overall business, brands and product lines. These statements are based on currently available operating, financial, economic and competitive information, and they are subject to a number of significant risk and uncertainties which could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. We described some of these uncertainties in the Risk Factor section of our 2008 annual report on Form 10-K, as well as our 2009 quarterly report on Form 10-Q, and in other filings we make with the SEC from time to time. Mattel does not update forward-looking statements and expressly disclaims any obligation to do so.Information required by Regulation G regarding non-GAAP financial measures is available on the Investor and Media section of our corporate website, mattel.com, under the subheading Financial Information and Earnings Releases. Now, I'd like to turn the call over to Bob.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dianne and good morning, everyone. At the beginning of 2009, I made some promises on behalf of these thousands of employees who work in Mattel. I said, "Our agenda is clear, to deliver improved execution, to position the company for the future
componenttext: Thank you, Dianne and good morning, everyone. At the beginning of 2009, I made some promises on behalf of these thousands of employees who work in Mattel. I said, "Our agenda is clear, to deliver improved execution, to position the company for the future and our promise is simple, to reward investors, run the business well and responsibly and make kids lives fun." And in 2009, we accomplished just that. We improved execution across the supply chain and throughout the company by realigning our infrastructure, controlling cost and expenses, tightly managing working capital, especially inventories, and reducing capital spending by doing only business-critical projects and doing them exceptionally well. The results is improved profitability, a stronger balance sheet and improved cash flow, which we used to lower debt, increase cash balances and continue to reward shareholders through our strong annual dividend. We were also successful in bringing magic to the lives of children through innovative new toys, including the revitalization of some of our classic and time honored brands, such as Barbie and Hot Wheels. Last year, as you know, we celebrated the 50th anniversary of the world's most iconic doll, and the worlds celebrated with us. This incredible milestone for the Barbie brand allowed us a unique platform to reconnect girls of all ages with the legacy of the brand: Fashion, aspiration and cultural relevance. And we connected with girls beyond the traditional 30-second television spot, Barbie was everywhere. We hosted global events like fashion shows and birthday bashes, made break through partnerships with fashion icons, like Karl Lagerfeld and Christian Louboutin, as well as with specialty retail outlets, like Pottery Barn and Sephora, and talk to girls in their own voice through social media outlets, like FaceBook and Twitter. And the results of all these cultural conversation, I'm proud to say, is that for the first time in years, all three brand-help indicators are headed in the right direction for Barbie. Our U.S. shipments in the retailers are up, retail takeaway is up, share is up. That's the trifecta, Barbie is back. And in 2010, we expect to build on the momentum we created in 2009. I'm also pleased to report growth across much of our portfolio in our Wheels business, both Hot Wheels and Matchbox, experienced strong global performance driven by continued strength in the core product lines, which includes basic cars and track and playsets, as well as key innovations, such as Hot Wheels' Color Shifters and Matchboxes' Rocky The Robot Truck, which was a sellout by the holidays. In our Other Girls business, the Little Mommy large doll line did very well in the holiday season, driven by a successful launch of our innovative Walk & Giggle Doll. As for our Games business, we so growth in core products, like Uno and Apples to Apples, as well as with our adult and family games, like Pictionary and Blokus. But the most exciting news in the Games arena was Mindflex, an early sellout and ultimately, one of the hottest toys of the year. Max Steel also enjoyed another year of record sales as Latin America's number one Boys Action brand. We also experienced success with our partners, with outstanding performance in our Disney Princess line, driven by core dolls, fashions and accessories, including robust sales lately in Europe [ph] that Princess and the Frog line. Disney Pixar's relaunch of the Toy Story franchise in fall 2009 drove performance with our Toy Story line of toys. Additionally, Disney Pixar Cars had another strong year, further establishing it as an evergreen brand. As you're well aware, we were awarded new toy licenses last year that are coming to life in 2010. WWE Wrestling and Heat Entertainment's Thomas and Friends have already hit store shelves, with Disney Pixar's Toy Story 3 hitting in  early summer. And even though 2009 was a year of sacrifice and hard work for Mattel employees, I'm extremely proud that for the third consecutive year, FORTUNE magazine has named Mattel to its 100 Best Companies to Work For list. Think about it, a year with essentially no performance bonus payouts, no merit or promotional salary increases and a significant reduction in force in our employees continue to proclaim their dedication and loyalty to our company. And like me, I know they're really looking forward to seizing the opportunities this year. As I've said throughout the past year, companies that deliver improved execution during the tough times will be the ones best positioned to capitalize on the economic turnaround which will most certainly occur. 2009 was important because it sets the stage for what I'm confident will be a strong year for Mattel in 2010 and for many years to come. And now for the financial review, Kevin?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob and good morning, everyone. As we've consistently said, we entered 2009 with a number of significant headwinds and plan to deliver results based upon realistic revenue assumptions, with our top priorities being to improve profitability, str
componenttext: Thank you, Bob and good morning, everyone. As we've consistently said, we entered 2009 with a number of significant headwinds and plan to deliver results based upon realistic revenue assumptions, with our top priorities being to improve profitability, strengthen the balance sheet and increase cash flow. Despite the headwinds that are still challenging us and the industry, I'm pleased to say, we did what we said. We delivered our 2009 priorities with profits and margins up versus last year, with $500 million more cash on hand than last year and finished the year with a stronger balance sheet. As I've done in previous years, I'll first review the results for the fourth quarter before reviewing full year results. For the fourth quarter, total worldwide gross sales for the quarter were flat, including a three percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. U.S. sales were down 2% while international sales were up 3%, including an eight percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. On a regional basis, sales in Europe were up 4%, including a nine percentage point positive impact from exchange rates. Sales in Latin America were flat, including a seven percentage point positive impact from foreign exchange. And sales in Asia-Pacific were up 8%, including a 16 percentage point positive impact from changes in the exchange rates. I'll now review our four categories and brands for the fourth quarter. Mattel Girls & Boys Brands. Worldwide sales for the Mattel Girls & Boys Brands segment were up 4%, including a six percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. Worldwide Barbie sales were up 12%, including a six percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. Barbie sales in the U.S. were up 9% and Barbie sales in the international markets increased 14%, including a nine percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. The worldwide sales for the quarter reflects strong performance in core lines, including Fashionistas and I CAN BE…, as well as hot products like the Camper and Townhouse. Consumer takeaway for Barbie in the U.S. was up double digits for the quarter, as well as full year, leaving U.S. retail inventories clean.Worldwide sales of Other Girls Brands were down 17%, including a five percentage point positive impact from changes in exchange rates. Sales in the U.S. were down 20% while international sales of Other Girls Brands were down 15%, including an eight percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. The worldwide sales decrease for the quarter was driven primarily by decline from the sales of High School Musical products. Sales in the Wheels business, which includes Hot Wheels, Speed Racer, Matchbox and Tyco R/C, increased 11% including a five percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. The worldwide sales increase for the quarter reflected strong performance in Hot Wheels and Matchbox, partially offset by sales declines in Tyco R/C and Speed Racer product.For core Hot Wheels, which exclude Speed Racer, worldwide sales were up 16%, including a six percentage point positive impact from foreign exchange. Domestic sales increased 13% and international sales increased 19%, including a 12 percentage point positive impact from foreign exchange. Sales in our Entertainment business, which includes games and puzzles, were up 2% including a five percentage point positive impact from changes in foreign exchange. For the quarter, excluding the positive impact of changes in foreign exchange, the worldwide sales decrease was driven primarily by lower sales of Radica and toys geared to prior year's three summer movie properties: Batman, Speed Racer and Kung Fu Panda. These declines were partially offset by sales of toys geared to Toy Story and Toy Story 2, solid performance in the Game business, along with the U.S. sales of Cars-related products [ph]. Fisher-Price Brands. Worldwide sales for Fisher-Price Brands were down 3% for the fourth quarter, including a three percentage point positive impact from changes in currency rates. On a regional basis, international sales of Fisher-Price Brands increased 3%, including a six percentage point positive impact from foreign exchange, while sales in the U.S. declined 7%. Worldwide core Fisher-Price was up 1%, including a three percentage point positive impact from changes in currency exchange rates. U.S. sales of Fisher-Price core were down 3% and international sales were up 6%, including a seven percentage point positive impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. The worldwide sales increase for the quarter was driven primarily by double-digit growth in Baby Gear, partially offset by disappointing sales of higher priced point key drivers. Worldwide Fisher-Price Friends sales declined 14%, including a two percentage point positive impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. Sales of Fisher-Price Friends in the U.S. were down 22% and international sales were down 3%, including a six percentage point positive impact from changes in foreign exchange. The worldwide sales decreased for the quarter primarily reflected the difficult comparison to a successful 2008 performance for Elmo Live and similar products. American Girl Brands. Fourth quarter sales of American Girl Brands were flat, reflecting solid performance in the retail channel, offset by softness in the direct channel primarily driven by a difficult comparison to strong Entertainment-related sales in 2008.I'll now review sales for the full year. Worldwide gross sales were down 9% for the full year, including a two percentage point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. U.S. sales are down 4%. International sales were down 13%, including a four percentage point negative impact from changes in currency exchange rates. On a regional basis, sales in Europe were down 15% compared to the prior year, including a four percentage point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. Sales in Latin America were down 12%, including a six percentage point negative impact from changes in exchange rates. And sales in Asia-Pacific were down 7%, including a two percentage point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange rates.I will now review our core categories and brands for the full year. Mattel Girls & Boys Brands, worldwide sales for Mattel Girls & Boys Brands decreased 10%, including a three percentage point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. The sales decrease reflect U.S. sales declines of 2% and international sales declines of 15%, including a negative impact from changes in currency exchange rates of four percentage points. Worldwide Barbie sales were down 3%, including a three percentage point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. Barbie sales in the U.S. were up 4% while on the international markets Barbie sales were down 6%, including a four percentage point negative impact from changes in exchange rates. Worldwide sales for Other Girls Brands were down 20%, which includes a two percentage point negative impact from changes in currency exchange rates. The worldwide sales performance for the full year was driven primarily by declines in sale of High School Musical products.Worldwide sales for the Wheels business were down 7%, which exclude a three percentage point negative impact from changes in currency exchange rates. The decline in worldwide sales reflected lower sales of Speed Racer product and Tyco R/C, partially offset by strong performances in Hot Wheels and Matchbox. For core Hot Wheels, worldwide sales were up 5%, including a three percentage point negative impact from foreign exchange. Domestic sales increased 17% and international sales declined 3%, including a five percentage point negative impact from foreign exchange.Sales in our Entertainment business, which includes Games and Puzzles were down 14%, with a two percentage point negative impact from changes in currency exchange rates. The worldwide sales decrease for the year was driven primarily by lower sales of Radica and toys geared to prior year's three summer movie properties: Batman, Speed Racer and Kung Fu Panda. These declines are partially offset by sales of toys geared to Toy Story and Toy Story 2, along with the U.S. sales of Cars-related properties. Fisher-Price Brands, worldwide sales for Fisher-Price Brands were down 8%, with a one percentage point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. U.S. sales were down 8%. International sales were down 9%, which include a four percentage point negative impact from changes in currency exchange rates. Worldwide sales at core Fisher-Price were down 6%, including a one percentage point negative impact from currency exchange rates. U.S. sales were down 4% and international sales decreased 9%, including a negative impact of four percentage points from changes in exchange rates. Worldwide sales of Fisher-Price Friends were down 13%, including no impact from currency exchange rates. U.S. sales declined 18%, while international sales were down 5%, including no impact from changes in foreign exchange.American Girl Brands. Full year sales of American Girl Brands were flat versus the prior year, driven primarily by the November 2008 openings of our two new boutique stores in Boston, Minneapolis, offset by softness, resulting primarily from a difficult comparison to strong Entertainment-related sales in 2008.Now let's review the P&L which is shown on Exhibit 1. For the fourth quarter, gross margin was 53.4%, up 740 basis points from 46% for the fourth quarter last year. Gross margin benefited primarily from price increases, savings from our Global Cost Leadership Program, favorable product cost and favorable mix, partially offset by foreign exchange.  For the year, gross margin was 50%, up 460 basis points from 45.4% in 2008. Compared with the prior year, gross margin benefited primarily from price increases, savings from our Global Cost Leadership Program, partially offset by foreign exchange. For the fourth quarter, advertising expense was $238.8 million, or 12.2% of net sales, versus 14.2% for the fourth quarter of 2008. For the year, advertising expenses was $609.8 million, or 11.2% in net sales, compared to 12.2% last year.For the quarter, selling, general, administrative expenses increased approximately $3.8 million to $388 million. As a percent to net sales, SG&A expense was 19.8% or flat compared with the prior year. The year-to-year dollar increase was primarily driven by higher prudent incentive compensation, partially offset by gross savings before severance of $25 million related to our Global Cost Leadership Program and a $22 million benefit for lower severance charges. SG&A also benefited from the absence of a $15 million legal settlement charge recorded in the fourth quarter of 2008.For the full year, SG&A expense is $1.37 billion, a decrease of $50 million from 2008. As a percent to net sales, SG&A increased by 120 basis points to 25.3%. The dollar decrease in SG&A was primarily driven by incremental year-over-year gross savings before severance of $88 million, related to our Global Cost Leadership Program, a benefit from foreign exchange and $27 million of lower litigation and legal settlement related cost. These savings were partially offset by $81 million of higher incentive compensation expense and $14 million of higher equity compensation expense. For the year, overall equity compensation expense was $50 million compared to $36 million in 2008. For the full year, our Global Cost Leadership Program delivered gross savings before severance of $164 million. The full year gross savings includes about $88 million in SG&A, $62 million in gross margin and $14 million in advertising. With $164 million of gross savings and $32 million of severance charges, we achieved 2009 net savings of $132 million from our Global Cost Leadership Program. As a reminder, in 2008, we had severance charges of about $35 million. We remain on track to deliver accumulative net savings of approximately $180 million to $200 million from this program by the end of 2010.Operating income in the fourth quarter was $417.4 million or 21.3% in net sales, up 930 basis points compared with last year's fourth quarter, due primarily to higher gross margins and lower advertising expenses. For the year, operating income was $731.2 million or 13.5% of net sales, up 430 basis points from the prior year, reflecting higher gross margins and lower advertising expenses, partially offset by higher SG&A as a percentage of net sales.For the fourth quarter, interest expense was $19.1 million, down from the prior-year fourth quarter of $28.9 million. For the full year, interest expense decreased from $81.9 million in 2008 to $71.8 million in 2009, due to lower average borrowings and lower average rates. Interest income for the quarter was $600,000 versus $3.2 million in 2008. For the year, interest income decreased from $25 million to $8.1 million, reflecting a lower yield on lower average cash balances through the year.In the fourth quarter, other non-operating expense net was $1.9 million versus income of $19 million in 2008. For the full year, other non-operating expense net was $7.5 million versus income of $3.1 million in 2008. The change in other non-operating income expense relates to foreign currency exchange gains and losses, primarily in Venezuela.The income tax provision for the year was $131.3 million compared to $108.4 million for 2008. The 2009 cash provision includes net benefits related to the prior years of $28.8 million or $0.08 a share, primarily due to reassessments of previously accrued taxes based upon the current status of federal, state and foreign audits. These benefits lowered the full year effective rate by 4.4 percentage points. For the full year 2010, we expect the tax rate to be about 27% based on current tax laws.For the fourth quarter, reported net income of $328.4 million or $0.89 per share versus last year's $176.4 million or $0.49 per share. For the year, reported net income of $538.7 billion or $1.45 per share versus last year's $379.6 million or $1.04 per share. So to summarize the P&L for 2009, the increase in full year net income resulted from higher gross margins, lower advertising expense and lower SG&A cost, partially offset by a decrease in sales volume. Now turning to the cash flow and balance sheet, cash flow from operations for the year was $945 million, driven primarily by net income of $529 million and working capital improvements of $261 million. Consistent with 2009 priorities for capital deployment, capital expenditures for the full year where $120.5 million down from last year's $198.8 million. In 2009, we also continued to reward our shareholders with a strong annual cash dividend at $0.75 per share, flat with the prior year.  Year-end cash on hand was $1.1 billion, up from approximately $618 million at the end of 2008, primarily due to strong cash flow generated from operations and disciplined capital deployment. Receivables were $749 million or 35 days of sales outstanding, down six days compared with last year.  Excluding the year-to-year change in factoring, receivables are down $45 million versus prior year, with days sales outstanding down two days versus prior year to 50 days. Inventories of $355.7 million were down $130 million or 27% versus 2008, primarily driven by a tight inventory management given the current economic environment and the lower cost of producing inventory in 2009. Additionally, [indiscernible] suggest retail inventory levels of our products with our major U.S. customers finished the year below prior-year levels.Our total balance sheet debt was $752 million, a decrease of $148 million from the prior year. During 2009, the company paid down $150 million of a maturing long-term debt. Our debt to total capital ratio ended the year at 22.9% versus 29.8% last year.So to summarize, as expected, Mattel experienced overall sales declines in 2009. However, our core brand performed well in terms of consumer takeaway then we executed on the things we control to deliver on our priorities of improving profitability and strengthening the balance sheet. As we've move into 2010, we feel much better about our top line growth prospects due to the benefit of new license entertainment properties we announced last year, a good momentum in our core brand portfolio. But we're also aware of the continuing challenges resulting from economic and employment conditions. In 2009, in terms of profitability, our gross margins rebounded nicely and we delivered as planned on our efficiency initiatives, resulting a return to low teens operating margins. While we are pleased with these results, our long-term performance goals for profitability are unchanged, with an overall operating margin goal of 15% to 20%. So for 2010, our focus will be to build upon our progress towards our profitability goal in the face of what we expect to be a challenging cost environment and a continuation of a difficult economic climate. As you heard from Bob, we believe our disciplined execution of what was a challenge in 2009 has positioned us well for 2010 in many years to come. That completes my review of financial results. Now we'd like to open the call to questions. Operator?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go first to Tim Conder with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go first to Tim Conder with Wells Fargo.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: As it relates to the gross margin again, Kevin, I think you said in your preamble that you had a -- FX was a negative in the quarter, I just wanted to double check that. And then how much would you attribute to your SKU rationalization benefiting gross ma
componenttext: As it relates to the gross margin again, Kevin, I think you said in your preamble that you had a -- FX was a negative in the quarter, I just wanted to double check that. And then how much would you attribute to your SKU rationalization benefiting gross margin in the quarter?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think with regard to gross margin at quarter, a negative 4x, yes, that really reflected the fact that for the first nine months of the year, ForEx was negative for the company and that flowed through in the fourth quarter. We'd see the benefits of
componenttext: Yes. I think with regard to gross margin at quarter, a negative 4x, yes, that really reflected the fact that for the first nine months of the year, ForEx was negative for the company and that flowed through in the fourth quarter. We'd see the benefits of a strengthening ForEx in the fourth quarter in next year. With regard to the SKU reduction, that was part of the benefit of getting improved margins but it was small, really a part of the Global Cost Leadership Program. If you look at our full year gross margins, they were to 50%, up 460 basis points from 45.4% in 2008. Compared with the prior year, gross margin benefited from price increases and savings from the Global Cost Leadership Program, which was about $62 million benefit for the full year. And only a small part of that benefit really impacted margin this year. We expect more benefits from that in 2010.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then could you make any comments -- Kevin, I think you alluded to it, that little bit on 2010, but how do you see the input cost to your -- looking into the year and I would expect it's going to be a little bit more of a headwind in the back half for
componenttext: And then could you make any comments -- Kevin, I think you alluded to it, that little bit on 2010, but how do you see the input cost to your -- looking into the year and I would expect it's going to be a little bit more of a headwind in the back half for the year?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've made good progress for building our gross margins in 2009 with, as I said, full year gross margins of 50%. Our goal is to sustain gross margins consistent with our long-term goal. And as you know, Tim, there's many factors impacting gro
componenttext: Yes. I think we've made good progress for building our gross margins in 2009 with, as I said, full year gross margins of 50%. Our goal is to sustain gross margins consistent with our long-term goal. And as you know, Tim, there's many factors impacting gross margins besides input cost like freight and distribution, world peace [ph], ForEx, mix in toy, to name a few. So predicting our gross margins is very difficult due to the complexity, all the moving pieces, the lack of transparency and predictability. But looking forward, we'll know we have royalty cost in 2010 due to our new entertainment partnerships, and we'll also -- possible predictable what will happen with commodity and labor markets, we're likely to see year-to-year cost increases. For example, there's been a steady recovery in crude oil price, as the current level about $75 a barrel, compared to $30 to $40 a barrel at this time a year ago. That said, we're going to continue to execute our Global Cost Leadership Program and other cost to manufacturing efficiency programs in 2010, and price our products consistent with making progress against a long-term annual goal of 15% to 20% operating margins.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, I'll ask the Avatar question. I don't think you ship too much in, in the fourth quarter but how did that sell through go? And anything you can say about what retailers are telling you, from a demand standpoint here, looking into the early
componenttext: And then lastly, I'll ask the Avatar question. I don't think you ship too much in, in the fourth quarter but how did that sell through go? And anything you can say about what retailers are telling you, from a demand standpoint here, looking into the early part of '10?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Bob. Obviously, retailers were very cautious about Avatar, given that it was a late December debut. And the timing of when the ban appeal hit from those sort of things was probably an issue. So we developed a full line but it was very targete
componenttext: Tim, this is Bob. Obviously, retailers were very cautious about Avatar, given that it was a late December debut. And the timing of when the ban appeal hit from those sort of things was probably an issue. So we developed a full line but it was very targeted and really more focused on collectors than it was for the younger audience. Sell through was fine but it wasn't a big contributor in 2009, for either retailers or for us. 2010 could be better. The DVD will come out, I don't know when it will come out, but perhaps more younger fans will see the property when the DVD comes out. So if retailers want to get behind it further, we have a line ready to go. But today, even though it's sold through nicely, it's not a big deal.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Tony Gikas with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Tony Gikas with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about how pricing held up over the holidays? There was a lot of noise at retail and a bit more noise in reality. Also, Fisher-Price is down, I think you said 7% in the U.S., maybe just the key driver there? And then also, at re
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about how pricing held up over the holidays? There was a lot of noise at retail and a bit more noise in reality. Also, Fisher-Price is down, I think you said 7% in the U.S., maybe just the key driver there? And then also, at retail, category shelf space, was that down a little bit over the holidays? What have we learned? And last question, can you update us on where we're at with the MGA process and legal fees?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: First, starting with pricing, it held up well this holiday season, our last holiday season. Obviously, different retailers have different promotional and marketing plans, some focus more heavily on price, others don't. In general, those retailers who didn
componenttext: First, starting with pricing, it held up well this holiday season, our last holiday season. Obviously, different retailers have different promotional and marketing plans, some focus more heavily on price, others don't. In general, those retailers who didn't focus as aggressively on price, did quite well and picked up some market share. So I think once again, there was evidence that we've now seen year after year, that one can sell toys. It's not a commodity, and it doesn't require huge price reductions to be successful in toys. The second question was about Fisher-Price. Business overall was a little soft last year. And in this case, it was particularly true in our higher-priced drivers. So we have made some adjustments in that line for 2010, both we and our customers are optimistic about the Fisher-Price line for 2010. Baby Gear rebounded a bit in the fourth quarter, that is the non-toy business in Fisher-Price. The Power Wheels and Friends were still soft. So we've got some work to do on Fisher-Price but overall, the sell through was good, and I think we've made the adjustments we need to make for 2010. What was the next question, Tony?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question was shelf space and then MGA?
componenttext: Next question was shelf space and then MGA?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Shelf space, I don't have a number off the top of my head for the overall industry. I don't think it was significantly changed. One retailer has talked about strategically emphasizing food and other sorts of things in its stores, and so there probably was
componenttext: Shelf space, I don't have a number off the top of my head for the overall industry. I don't think it was significantly changed. One retailer has talked about strategically emphasizing food and other sorts of things in its stores, and so there probably was a little bit of contraction there. But I don't know that I could conclude today that there was any big impact from shelf space on the toy business overall. I don't have real good data in front of me. And as it relates to MGA, the Court of Appeal hasn't yet issued any opinion addressing the merits of the case. But it has issued an order staying the equitable relief and that includes the transfer of the Bratz copyrights and the Bratz trademarks to Mattel. So in light of that development, we've put our 2010 Bratz line on hold until we hear further from the court. We do have a great line of dolls. We're confident girls are going to love them. And it's unfortunate we're not going to be able to proceed at this point. We are continuing with the mediation process that we began after the initial verdict and that was ordered as part of the stay execution. And we're preparing intensively for phase two of the trial, which could occur as early as this spring. And overall while we adduced legal expense in total in 2009 and we resolved much of the product recall litigation, we'll continue to make the appropriate level of investments and do the right thing, to defend our brands and our positions [indiscernible] until everything is resolved.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Legal fees in 2010 versus '09?
componenttext: Legal fees in 2010 versus '09?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, we've been incurring significant legal costs over the last couple of years related to MGA and the recall related litigation. For full-year 2008, we incurred incremental legal cost versus 2007 of about $37 million primarily for MGA litigation.
componenttext: As you know, we've been incurring significant legal costs over the last couple of years related to MGA and the recall related litigation. For full-year 2008, we incurred incremental legal cost versus 2007 of about $37 million primarily for MGA litigation. Litigation-related legal costs increased by $33 million from 2008 to 2009. Additionally in 2009, we recorded a $21 million charge related to legal settlement for product-liability related litigation. In 2008, $15 million was incurred with a connection with the recall-related multi-state settlement. Going forward, we expect legal fees related to recall-related litigation will be relatively minor given the recent legal settlement for product liability related litigation. As Bob said, we're still in litigation with MGA and incurring legal costs associated with the case being heard by the Court of Appeals. In addition, as Bob said, we're also incurring legal fees and we prepare for Phase II of the MGA trial which could occur as soon as spring of 2010. While we reduced expenses in 2009, we'll continue to make the appropriate level of investments in legal fees until the legal matters are resolved.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Felicia Hendrix with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: We'll go next to Felicia Hendrix with Barclays Capital.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: If you could just touch back on your international sales. I mean, obviously, Kevin, you ran through some of the details. But they were still weaker than I had expected. I was just wondering what were the drivers for that and how should we think about inte
componenttext: If you could just touch back on your international sales. I mean, obviously, Kevin, you ran through some of the details. But they were still weaker than I had expected. I was just wondering what were the drivers for that and how should we think about international, going forward? In other words, was there some particular that was happening in your international market please?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, not really, Felicia. There's no question in my mind that the economic conditions overseas have been more challenging, at least on our business compared to the conditions here in the U.S. Throughout the year, we saw some pretty widespread sales decline
componenttext: No, not really, Felicia. There's no question in my mind that the economic conditions overseas have been more challenging, at least on our business compared to the conditions here in the U.S. Throughout the year, we saw some pretty widespread sales declines in all major markets and across all major brands. So it wasn't a product line and a country or two or three or four or even, really made a difference. I think it's reasonable to conclude that there are just more retailers, either unable to buy or unwilling to buy or unable to pay. But all that being said, our international group really did a tremendous job in my mind delivering the P&L and balance sheet in the face of a tough revenue environment. They had solid margin improvement, whether it's gross margin or operating margins. They had tight inventory management and most importantly, they collected the cash. And I would say somewhat encouragingly, we did see a wee bit of sales momentum late in the year that really started with Barbie around the globe. So my view is we're not out of the woods yet, outside of the U.S. But we're clearly in a stronger position now than we were a year ago at the same time.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And did the inventory levels there reflect what you're seeing domestically, clean?
componenttext: And did the inventory levels there reflect what you're seeing domestically, clean?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We don't have quite the precision in the data that we do in the United States. But I don't have any reason to believe that inventories -- well, let me quit using triple negatives. I think it's reasonable to conclude that inventories were clean, virtu
componenttext: Yes. We don't have quite the precision in the data that we do in the United States. But I don't have any reason to believe that inventories -- well, let me quit using triple negatives. I think it's reasonable to conclude that inventories were clean, virtually everywhere in the world.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010

componenttext: On Thomas, is it going to be in Fisher-Price or entertainment or both?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's going to be in Fisher-Price, the Friends side of Fisher-Price.
componenttext: It's going to be in Fisher-Price, the Friends side of Fisher-Price.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So when we think about Fisher-Price and Thomas, does that offset Sesame Street?
componenttext: So when we think about Fisher-Price and Thomas, does that offset Sesame Street?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, nobody knows for sure. But if you look at the history of these properties, in general, the Thomas property has been the biggest licensed property in infant, preschool. The Sesame Street business at least for us has been more volatile. Some years the
componenttext: Well, nobody knows for sure. But if you look at the history of these properties, in general, the Thomas property has been the biggest licensed property in infant, preschool. The Sesame Street business at least for us has been more volatile. Some years there's a big hit product and some years there are not big hit products. And in general, our Sesame Street business has declined overall as the ratings of the television show have declined. But it's too early to predict sort of how it will play out over time.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010

componenttext: At your Investor Day this past summer, you were talking -- for just looking forward to 2011 for one moment, you talked about several properties and that you named. componenttext: Yes.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just go back through, one more time, just the FX headwinds in the fourth quarter? I didn't really understand your answer?
componenttext: Can you just go back through, one more time, just the FX headwinds in the fourth quarter? I didn't really understand your answer?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what you see is that, when you looked at the first nine months of the year, FX was a negative to the company. And when you think about our product flows, our product flows usually lag by a quarter. So if we manufacture product in the third qu
componenttext: Yes. I think what you see is that, when you looked at the first nine months of the year, FX was a negative to the company. And when you think about our product flows, our product flows usually lag by a quarter. So if we manufacture product in the third quarter, it goes through in the fourth quarter through the P&L. So ForEx was a negative in the third quarter, so it continues to be a negative in the fourth quarter.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then you should benefit...
componenttext: And then you should benefit...

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: See the benefit from ForEx in the fourth quarter, it ends up in the inventory on the balance sheet and then that inventory will flow through the P&L in the first quarter of 2010.
componenttext: See the benefit from ForEx in the fourth quarter, it ends up in the inventory on the balance sheet and then that inventory will flow through the P&L in the first quarter of 2010.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just, guys, I know this is a board decision [ph] but with things getting better with your cash flow being so strong, you're definitely not on hunker down mode anymore. Any thoughts on buybacks again?
componenttext: And then just, guys, I know this is a board decision [ph] but with things getting better with your cash flow being so strong, you're definitely not on hunker down mode anymore. Any thoughts on buybacks again?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think, Felicia, as we've said all year, our number one priority last year was to strengthen the balance sheet. We did increase cash, we did reduce debt and we also wanted to protect the dividend. And based on the meetings I had with folks throughou
componenttext: Well I think, Felicia, as we've said all year, our number one priority last year was to strengthen the balance sheet. We did increase cash, we did reduce debt and we also wanted to protect the dividend. And based on the meetings I had with folks throughout the year, I think there was a fair amount of speculation that we wouldn't be able to do that. So when I think about going forward, the economy certainly isn't out of the woods. And so we're going to continue to run a conservative cash flow machine and you're right, the board determines capital deployment. I know they're committed to the capital investment framework that we've laid out in 2002 or '03 or thereabouts. But fortunately, certainly compared to a year ago at this time, we kind of have a high-class problem today. That said, I doubt we're going to get ahead of ourselves. I don't have any specific comments on share repurchases other than -- as we do the analysis and look backwards in time at a lot of companies, share repurchases start to look like acquisitions. That is, if you read it [ph]  Through the backward analysis, most of them do not contribute to shareholder value. So we're going to be cautious about these things. Dividends today are more important in my mind's side than share repurchases but that's up to the board to decide.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Greg Badishkanian with Citi.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Greg Badishkanian with Citi.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a little bit of color on retail sales in the U.S., as well as internationally and how you think that compares with the industry?
componenttext: Maybe just a little bit of color on retail sales in the U.S., as well as internationally and how you think that compares with the industry?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in general, Greg, I would say we saw through NPD for the year, in the U.S. sales down about 1% for the industry. As we look at our sales at retail, whether we look at it at NPD or through the POS, we get directly from large customers, it was down ab
componenttext: Well, in general, Greg, I would say we saw through NPD for the year, in the U.S. sales down about 1% for the industry. As we look at our sales at retail, whether we look at it at NPD or through the POS, we get directly from large customers, it was down about 3%, kind of in that neighborhood. And so as we look at our retail inventories, they're clearly down. But remember, we finished 2008 with retail inventories as we calculate them about 8% over the prior year. We finished 2009 with the retail inventories down about 9%. So we've played out about as we expected. When we look at our performance at NPD, the industry as I've said, was down. I think it was some number like eight tenths of a percent, or 1%. We were down a little bit more than despite the fact that we did gain share in dolls and vehicles, in infant, in preschool. But it was a movie light year for us and in total, really because of the mix of categories, we lost a little bit of share here in the U.S. But I think all the numbers, as usual by the end of the year, sort of triangulate to the same thing.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: How about the fourth quarter?
componenttext: How about the fourth quarter?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't remember the number specifically for the fourth quarter in terms of the performance of NPD and POS. My recollection is our POS was quite a bit stronger than what NPD reported. But I really haven't gone through the quarterly data yet because frankl
componenttext: I don't remember the number specifically for the fourth quarter in terms of the performance of NPD and POS. My recollection is our POS was quite a bit stronger than what NPD reported. But I really haven't gone through the quarterly data yet because frankly, literally, we got the NPD data last night.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then as you look at your retailers, their inventories are pretty low as you've said. You think that out of stocks were higher this year than last year's, plus maybe some sales on the table because of the lower inventory levels?
componenttext: And then as you look at your retailers, their inventories are pretty low as you've said. You think that out of stocks were higher this year than last year's, plus maybe some sales on the table because of the lower inventory levels?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Some did and some didn't. Clearly, I think we had several retailers who think they lost some business because they were out of stock. But we have some other retailers who were in stock and who didn't give toys away at the end of the year and they did part
componenttext: Some did and some didn't. Clearly, I think we had several retailers who think they lost some business because they were out of stock. But we have some other retailers who were in stock and who didn't give toys away at the end of the year and they did particularly well. So I think it's a retailer-by-retailer sort of question. Obviously, our position is to make sure retailers have everything all the time, so we tell them how much sales they lost. But I don't think I overly generalized that.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just kind of looking at 2010, how do you think your toy lineup compares with your lineup in 2009, just kind of qualitatively in your view?
componenttext: And then just kind of looking at 2010, how do you think your toy lineup compares with your lineup in 2009, just kind of qualitatively in your view?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's better. Here's the problem. I think if you ask me that question each of the last 10 years, I'd answer the same. It's now, in my point of view, but that we've also shown our line of big chunk of our lineup for 2010 to retailers. They're very supportiv
componenttext: It's better. Here's the problem. I think if you ask me that question each of the last 10 years, I'd answer the same. It's now, in my point of view, but that we've also shown our line of big chunk of our lineup for 2010 to retailers. They're very supportive of our business. Some of the new stuff just looks fabulous to me. I mean if you go to stores today and look at Barbie, mermaid tails looks very good, the basic black dress segment of Barbie looks very good. I CAN BE… is doing very well. We've already got tens of thousands of girls voting on what Barbie's next career is going to be. I was in stores over the weekend, the WWE products that we've done is just fabulous. We've got products for both collectors and kids. And the collectors has a real level of precision and detail that they're going to appreciate. And for kids, there's this Force Flex (sic) [FlexForce] sort of, I think it's called technology where the toy actually does what the character does. And I was reading USA Today last week on an airplane and I was looking once again at the ratings, the top two shows in cable were WWE. So we've got some great properties. We clearly got more entertainment than we've had in the past. But I also have to tell you, our core brands are performing well in the market place. Hot Wheels has been up for several years. I think Matchbox finished its third year of really solid, I think in every case, double-digit POS growth. Fisher-Price is the one where it was a little soft this year and it's really just in the high priced key drivers and we've corrected that. So I think my optimism about 2010 is warranted but I'll also admit that that's the nature of the toy business in my view of toys.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the gross margins, obviously, very strong results there and nice increase. You mentioned a number of different drivers, what do you think the one or two biggest ones that led to the outperformance there?
componenttext: When you look at the gross margins, obviously, very strong results there and nice increase. You mentioned a number of different drivers, what do you think the one or two biggest ones that led to the outperformance there?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's really pricing and the Global Cost Leadership Program, as well as other efficiency programs outside of the Global Cost Leadership Program, manufacturing efficiency programs.
componenttext: It's really pricing and the Global Cost Leadership Program, as well as other efficiency programs outside of the Global Cost Leadership Program, manufacturing efficiency programs.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Remember, our gross margins are only back to where we want them to be in about where they were a few years ago. It's when the commodity cost ran up d our prices didn't go up quickly enough, we now over time made those adjustments. We got the prices right
componenttext: Remember, our gross margins are only back to where we want them to be in about where they were a few years ago. It's when the commodity cost ran up d our prices didn't go up quickly enough, we now over time made those adjustments. We got the prices right in the margins went back to where we expected. So we weren't all that surprised at strong gross margins year.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Linda Weiser with Caris.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Linda Weiser with Caris.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could go over any impacts from the Venezuelan Bolivar devaluation. Are you going to book a charge for balance sheet revaluation in the first quarter? And you have any -- met quantification of that? And also, are you gaining acc
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could go over any impacts from the Venezuelan Bolivar devaluation. Are you going to book a charge for balance sheet revaluation in the first quarter? And you have any -- met quantification of that? And also, are you gaining access at all to the official rate? Or do have to go into the parallel rate to transact going forward, in which case we may still see some negative impacts in your income statement?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think going to Venezuela, Venezuela accounts for about less than 3% of Mattel's sales volume. The devaluation of their currency announced in January 8 did not have a material impact on our results. We also don't expect to have a material impact on our 2
componenttext: I think going to Venezuela, Venezuela accounts for about less than 3% of Mattel's sales volume. The devaluation of their currency announced in January 8 did not have a material impact on our results. We also don't expect to have a material impact on our 2010 results because we typically obtain U.S. dollars at the parallel rate. So we continue to manage the risk associated with Venezuelan government and post-currency controls by prices and products based upon the expectations at local currency cost, requiring inventory in the U.S. dollars generally at the parallel rate. So generally, we more or less have been running the business based upon the parallel rate and have the official government rate. And. If we look at next year, there's actually inflationary accounting required in Venezuela and will be considered to be highly inflationary effective January 1, 2010. As a result, they will use to U.S. dollars as functional currency effective January 1, 2010, and local currency monetary assets and liabilities will be re- measured at the end of each reporting period, with the net adjustment being recorded in earnings additionally, Mattel uses the official rate to translate earnings in Venezuela to U.S. dollars in 2009. In 2010, Mattel expects to use the parallel rate to translate earnings. We estimate that Mattel's consolidated net income would have been reduced by less than $10 million in 2010 if we have used the parallel rate in 2009.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then can I just ask about advertising rates? Your advertising and promo ratio was down quite a bit in the fourth quarter. Is that just less spending, or are you benefiting from rates? And do you have any -- I know you don't like to project, but what d
componenttext: And then can I just ask about advertising rates? Your advertising and promo ratio was down quite a bit in the fourth quarter. Is that just less spending, or are you benefiting from rates? And do you have any -- I know you don't like to project, but what do you think the outlook is for 2010?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: One of the biggest change from a year ago was really the fact that our sales declined last year when the economy tanked and we've already made the advertising commitments. So my recollection is sales were down some number like 11% in the fourth quarter la
componenttext: One of the biggest change from a year ago was really the fact that our sales declined last year when the economy tanked and we've already made the advertising commitments. So my recollection is sales were down some number like 11% in the fourth quarter last year and we haven't planned that and we had committed the advertising dollars. And so this year as Kevin's mantra has been all year long, it was about realistic revenue assumptions in light of the economy, and we executed the advertising program almost exactly as we had planned it this year in terms of expenditures. There were some reductions, mostly a couple of things, part of our Global Cost Leadership Program. We consolidated some things and lowered some costs. We're obviously using more of social media, Twitter and FaceBook and those sorts of things, as opposed to television commercials. Overall, I think the number Kevin on a percent of sales was 11.2, some number like that, in all of 2009. And that range is about right for us. I think we've said some number like 11% to 13% over time, that's sort of what we've planned for.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Sean McGowan with Needham & Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Sean McGowan with Needham & Company.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at the inventory at the end of the year, on your books, the fact that your retail sell though was so strong better even than the sell in. Do you think that you lost some sales because you didn't have any inventory, just kind of a different view of
componenttext: Looking at the inventory at the end of the year, on your books, the fact that your retail sell though was so strong better even than the sell in. Do you think that you lost some sales because you didn't have any inventory, just kind of a different view of that earlier question on retail inventories?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sean, a bit. I mean, our inventory was down 27% last year. I think it was up, I don't know, some number like 11% or 13% the prior year. So it came down and I think about a quarter of the inventory decline this year is just the cost of goods, as oppos
componenttext: Yes, Sean, a bit. I mean, our inventory was down 27% last year. I think it was up, I don't know, some number like 11% or 13% the prior year. So it came down and I think about a quarter of the inventory decline this year is just the cost of goods, as opposed to real fewer units. It's not about order magnitude. We clearly left some business on the table on something like Mindflex or Barbie Fashionistas, as an example. But that's true every year. We've got 8,000 SKUs and we leave business out of the table at some and we've got too many of others. I don't know if we had to do it all of over again, that we have more inventory overall. We clearly would've had more on some products and less and on other products...

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: But when you cite something like Mindflex or Fashionistas, those are products that perhaps performed better than one might have reasonably expected our conservatively expected. So if you left money on the table, is because you could have sold more if you
componenttext: But when you cite something like Mindflex or Fashionistas, those are products that perhaps performed better than one might have reasonably expected our conservatively expected. So if you left money on the table, is because you could have sold more if you had built more. But here you got a situation where you actually have less, you built less. So will you just not expect as you did?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, in general across the company, the revenues for the year came in darn close than what we have thought they were going to be when we built the plan [ph] a year ago. We knew there were going to be three things working against us in 2009, they
componenttext: Yes. I think, in general across the company, the revenues for the year came in darn close than what we have thought they were going to be when we built the plan [ph] a year ago. We knew there were going to be three things working against us in 2009, they played out. Again, this isn't precise, but order magnitude about a third of the revenue decline was due to economic contraction, whether it's lower consumer purchases or certainly lower retailer purchases. About a third of the decline was lack of entertainment properties versus the prior year, and about a third of the decline was due to ForEx. We have planned it that way, it worked out that way. We built inventory that way and we focused on the cash flow that way, and it did what we expected it to do.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I think you said earlier when you're talking about kind of employee-morale type of issues. I think you said there were no merit bonuses, so could you square that with the recent incentive comp? Is there something I'm missing there that disconnect?
componenttext: Bob, I think you said earlier when you're talking about kind of employee-morale type of issues. I think you said there were no merit bonuses, so could you square that with the recent incentive comp? Is there something I'm missing there that disconnect?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's the timing of the payment. We had no bonuses last year in 2009. In 2008, based on 2008 performance, I got zero bonus in 2009. We also gave no merit increases or promotional increases at all in 2009 across the company. In 2010, Kevin has accrued
componenttext: Yes, it's the timing of the payment. We had no bonuses last year in 2009. In 2008, based on 2008 performance, I got zero bonus in 2009. We also gave no merit increases or promotional increases at all in 2009 across the company. In 2010, Kevin has accrued bonus based on our results in 2009 and we are expecting to get that cash out [ph].

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in orders of magnitude on incentive compensation recorded this year, it was $97 million versus last year, it was $15 million.
componenttext: Yes, I think in orders of magnitude on incentive compensation recorded this year, it was $97 million versus last year, it was $15 million.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The question that I will have then for 2010 is assuming that, for the sake of the question, we'll have another good year of compensation, but I would assume nowhere near the kind of increase that you saw in '09, is that right?
componenttext: The question that I will have then for 2010 is assuming that, for the sake of the question, we'll have another good year of compensation, but I would assume nowhere near the kind of increase that you saw in '09, is that right?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you go back, and I hit this the other day. If you go back at the 10 years that I've been here, we kind of have a target level of bonus. And if you look over a ten-year period of time, we're pretty close across the company to paying the target leve
componenttext: Yes. If you go back, and I hit this the other day. If you go back at the 10 years that I've been here, we kind of have a target level of bonus. And if you look over a ten-year period of time, we're pretty close across the company to paying the target level of bonus. That said, we rarely pay above the target level of bonus every year. I mean, we really do have a pay-for-performance philosophy here that works. So when the business doesn't do well, we don't get paid well and when the business does well, we do. And unfortunately, as you're kind of going through your P&L planning like we do in here, it's kind of hard to predict exactly how it's going to be. But the program works out well for us. And I think shareholders should be satisfied to know that we do well when they do well.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Final question regarding gross margins again, there's a lot of questions about it. So how would you characterize the sustainability of this current level? If you have kind of recaptured some lost ground over the last few years, knowing what you do know, w
componenttext: Final question regarding gross margins again, there's a lot of questions about it. So how would you characterize the sustainability of this current level? If you have kind of recaptured some lost ground over the last few years, knowing what you do know, which isn't everything, but about the headwinds that you might be facing, do you think this is a level that you can sustain, assuming no major changes in the product mix?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In general, Sean, yes. Now I'm not giving guidance, not on a [ph] go forward and that kind of level of stuff like that. But since the year 2000 I've said we kind of targeted a 50 gross margin or thereabouts. And it's going to change year in and year out.
componenttext: In general, Sean, yes. Now I'm not giving guidance, not on a [ph] go forward and that kind of level of stuff like that. But since the year 2000 I've said we kind of targeted a 50 gross margin or thereabouts. And it's going to change year in and year out. We made good progress, just about got there. Then we lost ground, primarily due to the commodities and the fact that our prices couldn't keep pace with the rapid growth of the commodities. We're now back on track. It's our goal to try and sustain good performance in gross margin, whether how we can do at any given three-month period of time or 12-month period of time, we'll see. But we're where we intended to be.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to John Taylor with Arcadia Investment Corp.
componenttext: And we'll go next to John Taylor with Arcadia Investment Corp.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at the products that were short in the fourth quarter, like Mindflex and maybe Fashionistas and so on, I guess, I'm thinking about the environment where many merchants were cautious about bringing in large quantities. Which of those -- could y
componenttext: If you look at the products that were short in the fourth quarter, like Mindflex and maybe Fashionistas and so on, I guess, I'm thinking about the environment where many merchants were cautious about bringing in large quantities. Which of those -- could you give us a list of things that you think have an additional afterlife in 2010, which in the past, might have been thought of as a kind of one and done kind of opportunity?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: JT, I don't know if I do a great list, but if you look at things like, my number one on my list is Mindflex. Mindflex, we wouldn't have intended [ph], it's a fascinating game. But it's not the kind of thing that's going to be an evergreen property and in
componenttext: JT, I don't know if I do a great list, but if you look at things like, my number one on my list is Mindflex. Mindflex, we wouldn't have intended [ph], it's a fascinating game. But it's not the kind of thing that's going to be an evergreen property and in our mind's eye when we launched it, it was probably a one-year property. Well, it's going to carry forward into 2010 and now we've got some ideas to extend the technology and do some new things with it. So that's a big one. Matchbox's Rocky The Robot, that was a sellout. We've got some follow-up products to Rocky. The one that we're introducing this year, I think is a really, really cool Matchbox item that will be showing hopefully at Toy Fair. Uno Moo, is another one that was kind of Uno-meets-Fisher-Price farm and that worked out very well. That was a sellout. There were several things in the Barbie line that's sold out, the  3 Story Townhouse (sic) [3 Story Dream Townhouse], the Camper, the Fashionistas line. Barbie really sold through incredibly well. But again, JT, if you look at the 8,000 SKUs and the one we rarely talk about every -- the bottom ones on the tale [ph] where we made too many. Fortunately, if our inventory down 27% last year, we didn't make [ph] too many of those.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: As you look at your, the gross margin components going into 2010, I wonder -- you said I think that part of the improvement in 2009 was a mix shift in favor of higher-margin stuff. So as you get the new entertainment properties in, is there anything in pa
componenttext: As you look at your, the gross margin components going into 2010, I wonder -- you said I think that part of the improvement in 2009 was a mix shift in favor of higher-margin stuff. So as you get the new entertainment properties in, is there anything in particular you've got your eye on that might drag the gross margin down because of influence on mix?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, royalties in general. Those products in general that carry royalties, that is somebody else's intellectual property, have lower gross margins than our internal intellectual property. That being said, from an operating margin standpoint, they're very
componenttext: Yes, royalties in general. Those products in general that carry royalties, that is somebody else's intellectual property, have lower gross margins than our internal intellectual property. That being said, from an operating margin standpoint, they're very similar because obviously, somebody else is building the intellectual property and investing more in advertising than we need to.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And as you ramp up on the new properties through [ph] many years like WWE and Thomas and so on, is there kind of a gross margin curve? Or do you pretty much hit the ground running with tooling cost [ph] and all that stuff, as that deploys out through the
componenttext: And as you ramp up on the new properties through [ph] many years like WWE and Thomas and so on, is there kind of a gross margin curve? Or do you pretty much hit the ground running with tooling cost [ph] and all that stuff, as that deploys out through the year?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to guest, Kevin, we pretty much hit the ground running.
componenttext: I'm going to guest, Kevin, we pretty much hit the ground running.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's right, Bob.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's right, Bob.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010

componenttext: In your 10-Qs and Ks, you break out the cost to sales numbers by product, royalty and freight and so on, could you share those with us this morning or do we have to wait for the K?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
