componenttext: Kevin, can you give us what the depreciation and amortization was in the quarter?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can. Just give me a second on that, Sean.
componenttext: Yes, I can. Just give me a second on that, Sean.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then another question then related to previous questions is, on the gross margin improvement, could you -- as you've done in the past, could you sort of give us an idea of what are the factors that drove it higher, kind of which was more important? So if
componenttext: Then another question then related to previous questions is, on the gross margin improvement, could you -- as you've done in the past, could you sort of give us an idea of what are the factors that drove it higher, kind of which was more important? So if you're looking at price, cost cuts and input costs, how do they rank out in terms of what influenced the head?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll answer the first question. It's about $41 million for the quarter versus about $44 million last year. Then looking at the first quarter gross margin, the first quarter gross margins grew by 510 basis points to 49.1% compared to last year's firs
componenttext: Okay, I'll answer the first question. It's about $41 million for the quarter versus about $44 million last year. Then looking at the first quarter gross margin, the first quarter gross margins grew by 510 basis points to 49.1% compared to last year's first quarter gross margin of 44%. And gross margin benefited primarily from favorable product costs, savings from the Global Cost Leadership Program, price increases and favorable mix. This quarter, we continue to benefit from lower-commodity cost markets that occurred last year when we were buying input costs and manufacturing for our 2010 product line. Our 2010 gross margins also improved due to continuous improvement programs related to our Global Cost Leadership Program and other manufacturing efficiency programs across our supply chain. We've made good progress in rebuilding gross margins, and our goal is to sustain gross margins consistent with our long-term goal.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the past, though, I think you've said things along the lines of 1/3 of the increase or decrease in subquarters have come from X and 1/3 came from Y, are they kind of equally contributing to the equation in the first quarter?
componenttext: In the past, though, I think you've said things along the lines of 1/3 of the increase or decrease in subquarters have come from X and 1/3 came from Y, are they kind of equally contributing to the equation in the first quarter?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think the biggest impact was the favorable product costs, followed by savings in the Global Cost Leadership Program, which is about $11 million in the quarter related to gross margins, net price increases and then favorable mix. Exactly the orders i
componenttext: No, I think the biggest impact was the favorable product costs, followed by savings in the Global Cost Leadership Program, which is about $11 million in the quarter related to gross margins, net price increases and then favorable mix. Exactly the orders in magnitude.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Bob, just if you can give us a little color on within the Barbie line, what seems to be driving that? I mean, you're up against a pretty tough number in the first quarter in the U.S. Anything particular that stood out as working well within Barbie, a
componenttext: And, Bob, just if you can give us a little color on within the Barbie line, what seems to be driving that? I mean, you're up against a pretty tough number in the first quarter in the U.S. Anything particular that stood out as working well within Barbie, and do you think it's sustainable?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is, Sean. We continue to experience good momentum on Barbie. POS is increasing, even when we compare it to last year's 50th birthday celebration of Barbie. The I Can Be... segment is performing particularly well. You will recall we launched Bar
componenttext: Yes, there is, Sean. We continue to experience good momentum on Barbie. POS is increasing, even when we compare it to last year's 50th birthday celebration of Barbie. The I Can Be... segment is performing particularly well. You will recall we launched Barbie's 125th and 126th careers during the quarter. The spring entertainment, which is Barbie in a mermaid tail, is doing well. Fashionistas are doing well. Our Barbie Basics are doing well, that's the Little Black Dress line right now. So I think there's no question that Barbie is gaining share and continues to have a good momentum. And beyond Barbie, Disney Princesses is doing very well, both in the U.S. and abroad. We've had good success with the Princess and the Frog line. The DVD was released just a couple of weeks ago. And I think Disney Princesses is going to do well all year, particularly as we approach the fall movie, Tangled, which is the Rapunzel story. And that -- probably the offset there, to some degree, is High School Musical. But the momentum we have on Disney Princesses was pretty solid.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Drew Crum of Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Crum of Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to the cost of goods sold. I think you mentioned Chinese currency being an item. I know it's been in the news quite a bit recently, and I think we've talked about the impact. But can you talk about strategies you guys have in place
componenttext: I just want to go back to the cost of goods sold. I think you mentioned Chinese currency being an item. I know it's been in the news quite a bit recently, and I think we've talked about the impact. But can you talk about strategies you guys have in place in the event the Chinese government will let the won float? Are you doing an anticipation of that?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as you know, Drew, the vast majority of the world's toys are produced in China. The majority of our toys are produced in China. But we are one of the few folks that also manufactures our own toys and manufactures toys in markets other than China, inc
componenttext: Yes, as you know, Drew, the vast majority of the world's toys are produced in China. The majority of our toys are produced in China. But we are one of the few folks that also manufactures our own toys and manufactures toys in markets other than China, including Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and Mexico. So we're relatively less dependent on China than the rest of the toy world, but it's still very important to us.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I guess, Drew, I look at it as just another cost pressure, the same as our look at the input cost, labor costs. So it's just another cost pressure that we've got to -- when we consider pricing our products, the price for the new real will be in c
componenttext: Yes. And I guess, Drew, I look at it as just another cost pressure, the same as our look at the input cost, labor costs. So it's just another cost pressure that we've got to -- when we consider pricing our products, the price for the new real will be in cost.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Bob, could you comment on what you saw in terms of performance for the new entertainment properties, domestic versus international? And I guess, specifically WWE?
componenttext: And, Bob, could you comment on what you saw in terms of performance for the new entertainment properties, domestic versus international? And I guess, specifically WWE?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're off to really a solid start on all of the new properties: Toy Story; in the Fisher-Price segment, the Thomas property is off to a really nice start; and WWE. WWE has done well globally. It's not a big factor in every market around the world. But cle
componenttext: We're off to really a solid start on all of the new properties: Toy Story; in the Fisher-Price segment, the Thomas property is off to a really nice start; and WWE. WWE has done well globally. It's not a big factor in every market around the world. But clearly, I think we're going to build an international presence for WWE. If anything, we've been struggling in the past several months to keep up with demand for WWE. So it's off to a really nice start. And broadly speaking, I'd say, all of the new properties are performing well globally, with pretty big performance everywhere in the world where those properties have been supportive.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And last question, it doesn't look like you guys did a share repo during the quarter. Could you just update us on your thoughts on uses cash? You're sitting on close to $900 million of cash in the balance sheet. We expect you to generate some cash flow du
componenttext: And last question, it doesn't look like you guys did a share repo during the quarter. Could you just update us on your thoughts on uses cash? You're sitting on close to $900 million of cash in the balance sheet. We expect you to generate some cash flow during the year. What are your updated thoughts on uses of cash?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Drew, I'd start by reminding everyone that last year, given the macroenvironment, we were really in hunker-down mode around here. We said a year ago that our priorities for 2009 were to strengthen the balance sheet, we wanted to increase cash, re
componenttext: I guess, Drew, I'd start by reminding everyone that last year, given the macroenvironment, we were really in hunker-down mode around here. We said a year ago that our priorities for 2009 were to strengthen the balance sheet, we wanted to increase cash, reduce debt and protect the dividend. We were successful in achieving our goals last year. So as we look at 2010, we're transitioning back to our capital and investment framework which we developed in 2002 or 2003 and have been using ever since. In the end, capital deployment is a Board-level decision. But I can tell you that we have recently reaffirmed the key tenants of our framework with the Board, and there aren't really going to be any changes in the near future.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Taylor of Arcadia Investment.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Taylor of Arcadia Investment.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, Thailand seems to be in the news again here, so I wonder if you might talk about that a little bit from a supply security side of things. And the other thing, I guess, would be sort of container capacity out there, things that can happen in remote pl
componenttext: One, Thailand seems to be in the news again here, so I wonder if you might talk about that a little bit from a supply security side of things. And the other thing, I guess, would be sort of container capacity out there, things that can happen in remote places and whatnot. So that would be the first operational question. And then, Bob, I wonder if you could expand a little bit on your opening comments about sort of the new Mattel and the new decade we're looking at. What are we seeing executed this year? And if there's anything you can sort of foreshadow for us for next year, what the implications of the out-of-the-box thinking might be for play.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: First as it relates to Thailand, we have a good presence in Thailand. Our operations and supply chain really haven't been materially affected by what's going on over there. And in history, at least in the 10 years since I have been here, there's usually o
componenttext: First as it relates to Thailand, we have a good presence in Thailand. Our operations and supply chain really haven't been materially affected by what's going on over there. And in history, at least in the 10 years since I have been here, there's usually one or two places that are of concern from a supply-chain standpoint, and we're not solely dependent on one area of the world. So even if we run into hiccups, we generally have an ability to overcome those, and I would say the situation in Thailand is consistent with that right now. As you think about the company going forward, I really think over the last decade, we've been very focused and very disciplined, and it has served us well. We have built shareholder value. We look at the benchmarks and what's happened over the past 10 years, and I'm generally pleased with the progress we've made. As we think about the company going forward, one of the points I wanted to make in the opening comments is, it is evolution, not revolution. But we think there's a lot of potential in value and thinking more about play. Toys are certainly an important component of play. And I think 10 years from now, if all goes well, we're going to continue being the leading toy company in the world. But we see avenues for growth in the years ahead beyond just traditional toy play. As an example, we're doing a lot of work right now in the digital space. And we know kids are playing digitally and they're playing with our brands digitally, and they're staying in the marketplace longer than they used to. I remember kids [ph] (59:50) in 2000, I remember talking about kids getting older and younger, and a lot of us seemed focused on that phenomenon. In fact, today, kids seem to be playing with our brands in the ages that are inconsistent with kids getting older and younger. They're just playing in a different way. And we have to figure that all out, we have to figure out how to generate revenues out of that and how to make money in that. But I think that's one example of a new avenue of growth for the company, and hopefully, profitable growth when we think about the years to come.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could call out anything that's going on in China as it relates to the retail store, and the footprint you're trying to build there and consumer reaction.
componenttext: I wonder if you could call out anything that's going on in China as it relates to the retail store, and the footprint you're trying to build there and consumer reaction.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The store is okay, not great. If you look at that store as how many toys it sells relative to all the toys sold by all the retailers in Shanghai or even in China, it's actually performing quite well. But you still have to think about the future potential
componenttext: The store is okay, not great. If you look at that store as how many toys it sells relative to all the toys sold by all the retailers in Shanghai or even in China, it's actually performing quite well. But you still have to think about the future potential of China and the future potential of Barbie in China. And as much as anything else, that store is designed to sort of introduce China to Barbie. Generally speaking, when we're talking about Barbie or talking about all of our brands in China, we're seeing good growth. We didn't grow last year in China as kind of a global economy into as well as it had previously, but we've kind of picked up again this year in virtually all of the emerging economies like China and India. That being said, while the growth rates look really good and it's really impressive when you put the percentage signs next to them, it's off of a very small base. We're making progress, but it's really a long-term strategy, still not material for the company.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, JT, with respect to your question out of containers, every year we've got challenges in our supply chain and we manage through those. We haven't heard anything yet about having container capacity issue here for the fall.
componenttext: And then finally, JT, with respect to your question out of containers, every year we've got challenges in our supply chain and we manage through those. We haven't heard anything yet about having container capacity issue here for the fall.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I think with regard to -- if you look at RMB, it's a small percentage because it's really -- most of it relates to labor and local value add. And if you look at a 1% movement in the RMB, it has about a $5 million impact, positive and negative based upon there.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, just going to some of the entertainment properties, it seems like Toy Story kind of got off the ground earlier than we were expecting with some pretty strong retail support. Just big picture, I mean, do you guys see that as too being incremental
componenttext: Actually, just going to some of the entertainment properties, it seems like Toy Story kind of got off the ground earlier than we were expecting with some pretty strong retail support. Just big picture, I mean, do you guys see that as too being incremental so it adds to the pile over 2010, or slightly point things forward over some later quarters?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say, generally speaking, Rob, Toy Story is consistent with our expectations right now. We had good success with Toy Story last year. And as I've been out at retail stores so far this year, we see continued good performance of the sort of core fran
componenttext: No, I'd say, generally speaking, Rob, Toy Story is consistent with our expectations right now. We had good success with Toy Story last year. And as I've been out at retail stores so far this year, we see continued good performance of the sort of core franchise Toy Story products. And as I mentioned, over the next couple of weeks here, we ought to start to see strong support for Toy Story 3. So my view of Toy Story is that it is an evergreen property like Cars, which is now in its fifth year for us, it has been an evergreen property. And like we think WWE and Thomas will be. So that's one of the things that is most exciting to me right now, is that we've got our hands on these brands, and they're really brands, not just movie properties.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two other quick ones. Is the full Thomas line out on market yet? I guess back at Toy Fair, I don't think it had fully been launched yet.
componenttext: Two other quick ones. Is the full Thomas line out on market yet? I guess back at Toy Fair, I don't think it had fully been launched yet.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I really don't think it is based on -- I was in stores last weekend and I still see some of the segments in which we're now selling products represented by older products. So I think there is still going to be some transition to Thomas. That being said, T
componenttext: I really don't think it is based on -- I was in stores last weekend and I still see some of the segments in which we're now selling products represented by older products. So I think there is still going to be some transition to Thomas. That being said, Thomas, again, is consistent with our expectations and doing very well. But just my observation, for what it's worth, is that we're still not fully through the pipeline in seeing our products on shelf everyday.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, just on Monsters, any sort of update on that or tie into your expanding the play area, comments on the broader books to reaching entertainment properties?
componenttext: Actually, just on Monsters, any sort of update on that or tie into your expanding the play area, comments on the broader books to reaching entertainment properties?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that's an interesting part of the strategy going forward. I think we're going to do an Analyst Day here coming up in the spring. And Dianne promises me that sooner or later, we're going to have to talk more specifically about Monsters, and I've told h
componenttext: No, that's an interesting part of the strategy going forward. I think we're going to do an Analyst Day here coming up in the spring. And Dianne promises me that sooner or later, we're going to have to talk more specifically about Monsters, and I've told her I think it might be a good idea to do that then.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Margaret Whitfield of Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Margaret Whitfield of Sterne Agee.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wondered, Bob, you mentioned the Easter shift as it related to American Girl. If you could give us some commentary as to how the earlier Easter benefited your top line in Q1 and what might occur as a result in Q2.
componenttext: I wondered, Bob, you mentioned the Easter shift as it related to American Girl. If you could give us some commentary as to how the earlier Easter benefited your top line in Q1 and what might occur as a result in Q2.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it had some effects, Margaret. It's hard to tell. But I think from my vantage point, the easiest way to think about it is, in the first quarter of 2009, my recollection is American Girl was down 4% in sales, and in the first quarter of 2010,
componenttext: Yes, I think it had some effects, Margaret. It's hard to tell. But I think from my vantage point, the easiest way to think about it is, in the first quarter of 2009, my recollection is American Girl was down 4% in sales, and in the first quarter of 2010, it was up 6% in sales. Easter is one relatively-small component of that. There are a lot of other things going out in American Girl, like the store is doing well, like, as Kevin mentioned, Lanie doing particularly well compared to the prior year's Girl of the Year. But generally speaking, I think that -- clearly, the earlier Easter had some impact. I think, personally, it's a fairly minor impact, but a positive impact in this quarter at the expense of next quarter.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was referring to the entire company. So you think it's a minor impact in Q1?
componenttext: I was referring to the entire company. So you think it's a minor impact in Q1?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I do. We don't know what the second quarter is going to look like yet, so we'll see. But in my experience of doing this for a while now, it tends to be a little bit of a shift from the first quarter to the second quarter or vice versa, but not a big deal.
componenttext: I do. We don't know what the second quarter is going to look like yet, so we'll see. But in my experience of doing this for a while now, it tends to be a little bit of a shift from the first quarter to the second quarter or vice versa, but not a big deal.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on Barbie, the U.S. did extremely well against tough numbers. International was flat with currency positive. Could you comment on why international lagged although the comparisons, as I recall, are easier?
componenttext: And then on Barbie, the U.S. did extremely well against tough numbers. International was flat with currency positive. Could you comment on why international lagged although the comparisons, as I recall, are easier?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Margaret, I think as we've rationalized the line, particularly internationally, we focused more on fashions in this year in the Career Aspirations segments. So we've seen declines on My Scene, which is a relatively larger line outside the U.S. than i
componenttext: Yes, Margaret, I think as we've rationalized the line, particularly internationally, we focused more on fashions in this year in the Career Aspirations segments. So we've seen declines on My Scene, which is a relatively larger line outside the U.S. than in the U.S. where it's has been discontinued, and especially in the Younger Princes segment overseas. So as we transition to Disney Princess in Europe, for example, we're clearly looking to build that business.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you give us an update on the MGA situation, Phase II and the appellate court?
componenttext: And could you give us an update on the MGA situation, Phase II and the appellate court?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there really isn't much. In December, the Ninth Circuit heard MGA's arguments for its appeal of the trial court's orders that granted an injunction against MGA and the other equitable relief to Mattel. The orders were originally issued by the trial
componenttext: Well, there really isn't much. In December, the Ninth Circuit heard MGA's arguments for its appeal of the trial court's orders that granted an injunction against MGA and the other equitable relief to Mattel. The orders were originally issued by the trial court after the 2008 unanimous jury verdict against MGA and Mr. Larian. The court hasn't yet issued any opinion addressing the merits of the case. But in December, it ordered a stay on the equitable relief, including the transfer of Bratz, the registrations and the trademarks and those things to Mattel. So we're still awaiting the Ninth Circuit's opinion. And at the same time, we are very busy preparing for the next phase of the case, which focuses on trade secret theft, among other things.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is that in Q2, the beginning of Phase II?
componenttext: Is that in Q2, the beginning of Phase II?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we really don't know. I think it will happen fairly quickly after the Ninth Circuit opines on the first phase of the case. We're certainly gearing up for that. So we're ready to go whenever the time comes. But I have no clue whether that will be sec
componenttext: Well, we really don't know. I think it will happen fairly quickly after the Ninth Circuit opines on the first phase of the case. We're certainly gearing up for that. So we're ready to go whenever the time comes. But I have no clue whether that will be second quarter, third quarter, fourth quarter or whenever.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, you mentioned Tangled as probably a strong property in the second half, and I know Toy Story and WWE and Thomas will likely be. Anything else to call out post Toy Fair in terms of where the retailers are placing their bets in terms of your new li
componenttext: Finally, you mentioned Tangled as probably a strong property in the second half, and I know Toy Story and WWE and Thomas will likely be. Anything else to call out post Toy Fair in terms of where the retailers are placing their bets in terms of your new line?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think we got it covered. I think when we get to the Monsters property, that's going to start. Exactly how that plays out is yet to be seen, but I don't think its going to be a big deal for this year's numbers. I think we've got all the drivers alrea
componenttext: No, I think we got it covered. I think when we get to the Monsters property, that's going to start. Exactly how that plays out is yet to be seen, but I don't think its going to be a big deal for this year's numbers. I think we've got all the drivers already in place for this year.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Felicia Hendrix of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Felicia Hendrix of Barclays.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, just circling back to the gross margins. One of the items, although it was the least important, was the favorable mix. And I'm just wondering, I'm trying to understand that. Other than Barbie increasing, which is obviously more profitable, what els
componenttext: Kevin, just circling back to the gross margins. One of the items, although it was the least important, was the favorable mix. And I'm just wondering, I'm trying to understand that. Other than Barbie increasing, which is obviously more profitable, what else in your line contributed to this favorable mix?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It was really all the performance of the core brands where we don't pay royalties. So we saw good growth in core brands.
componenttext: It was really all the performance of the core brands where we don't pay royalties. So we saw good growth in core brands.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Bob, on the strength of Disney Princesses, besides Princess and the Frog, was there anything else or is it just that?
componenttext: And then, Bob, on the strength of Disney Princesses, besides Princess and the Frog, was there anything else or is it just that?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say it's just that. I think the line, broadly speaking, is doing well. If you look at the product line, if you look at just physically the products that we're introducing in Europe as we speak, and it's been a pretty slow transition in Europe b
componenttext: I wouldn't say it's just that. I think the line, broadly speaking, is doing well. If you look at the product line, if you look at just physically the products that we're introducing in Europe as we speak, and it's been a pretty slow transition in Europe because there's a fair amount of old products still in the marketplace. But if you look at the Princess dolls that we have created and compare those to the Princess dolls that have been in the marketplace in Europe, in my judgment, it's night and day better. And I think we've got some great products, we've had very strong retail support, and so I think that franchise is doing particularly well, not just one individual item. That having been said, we've had very good success with Princess and the Frog. And it's clearly been one of the key drivers, and I think it's going to continue to do well.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the shipment for Thomas and WWE going forward, should it be adjusting for seasonality? Should the shipments basically be even throughout the year or do we see more in the first half? Or is it like everything else that's just core ever
componenttext: And then in terms of the shipment for Thomas and WWE going forward, should it be adjusting for seasonality? Should the shipments basically be even throughout the year or do we see more in the first half? Or is it like everything else that's just core evergreen, it just kind of comes throughout the year and just obviously, adjusting for the seasonality?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's like everything else. I don't think those are unique. Certainly, Toy Story will be a little different because of the entertainment coming up in June of this year. But if you think about something about like Thomas, I don't think there's an un
componenttext: I think it's like everything else. I don't think those are unique. Certainly, Toy Story will be a little different because of the entertainment coming up in June of this year. But if you think about something about like Thomas, I don't think there's an unusual seasonality to Thomas.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, and I think, in general, 30% of our sales are done in the first half of the year and 70% is done in the back half. I don't see any difference in Thomas and WWE from that.
componenttext: No, and I think, in general, 30% of our sales are done in the first half of the year and 70% is done in the back half. I don't see any difference in Thomas and WWE from that.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, Kevin, in prior quarters, you would break out the components of the Cost Leadership Program savings. So you said it was $11 million in the quarter, how does that split among SG&A, advertising and cost of goods sold?
componenttext: And then just finally, Kevin, in prior quarters, you would break out the components of the Cost Leadership Program savings. So you said it was $11 million in the quarter, how does that split among SG&A, advertising and cost of goods sold?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think with respect to the Global Cost Leadership Program, in the first quarter, we delivered gross savings before severance of approximately $17 million, as I said, in addition to the $5 million of gross savings reflected in SG&A. As I said, there'
componenttext: Yes, I think with respect to the Global Cost Leadership Program, in the first quarter, we delivered gross savings before severance of approximately $17 million, as I said, in addition to the $5 million of gross savings reflected in SG&A. As I said, there's roughly $11 million of savings in gross margin and $1 million in advertising expense. With $17 million in gross savings and $2 million of severance charges, we achieved net savings of $15 million from our Global Cost Leadership Program. And we remain on track to deliver a cumulative net savings of approximately $180 million to $200 million from the program by the end of 2010.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Greg Badishkanian from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Greg Badishkanian from Citigroup.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the cost-cutting program, the $180 million to $200 million target, you said you're on track. Just wondering if sales continue -- momentum continues to be strong like it was this quarter, do you think it's still achievable or do some of those costs
componenttext: Just on the cost-cutting program, the $180 million to $200 million target, you said you're on track. Just wondering if sales continue -- momentum continues to be strong like it was this quarter, do you think it's still achievable or do some of those costs rise, making it not as achievable?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think as I said, we're on track to deliver the $180 million to $200 million, and I don't see volume changing that. I think we're reflected or focused in  on specific programs to cut costs, those things like SKU rationalization, clustering of our Eur
componenttext: No, I think as I said, we're on track to deliver the $180 million to $200 million, and I don't see volume changing that. I think we're reflected or focused in  on specific programs to cut costs, those things like SKU rationalization, clustering of our European operations, we're working on consolidating our Southern California distribution centers, we're working on outsourcing our IT infrastructure. So there's programs that are independent of our top line revenue growth.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any sort of color on competitive environment there that maybe helped you in terms of MGA, in terms of what shelf space they have getting and what they're expecting to get sort of in the fall ahead of Christmas?
componenttext: Any sort of color on competitive environment there that maybe helped you in terms of MGA, in terms of what shelf space they have getting and what they're expecting to get sort of in the fall ahead of Christmas?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm always fascinated to hear how they comment on their business, so I don't think I'd do that.
componenttext: I'm always fascinated to hear how they comment on their business, so I don't think I'd do that.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any other sort of color in terms of what you've been seeing over the last few months? Any changes in the competitive environment?
componenttext: Any other sort of color in terms of what you've been seeing over the last few months? Any changes in the competitive environment?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think Barbie has good momentum. As I mentioned, Disney Princesses has good momentum. Other brands come and go, but we've been at this for a long time and things seem to be going pretty well.
componenttext: No, I think Barbie has good momentum. As I mentioned, Disney Princesses has good momentum. Other brands come and go, but we've been at this for a long time and things seem to be going pretty well.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on the third quarter call, you talked about Toy Story I think being $100 million business during the movie year. And just kind of -- as you kind of look out, how well do you think that could be relative to that year? Obviously, stronger, but
componenttext: And then just on the third quarter call, you talked about Toy Story I think being $100 million business during the movie year. And just kind of -- as you kind of look out, how well do you think that could be relative to that year? Obviously, stronger, but how much stronger do you think?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know if I said that, Greg. If Kevin said that, I'll strangle him. I may have said something from what you can infer, like a good movie property is $100 million or more, and there's every reason to believe Toy Story is going to be a good movi
componenttext: Well, I don't know if I said that, Greg. If Kevin said that, I'll strangle him. I may have said something from what you can infer, like a good movie property is $100 million or more, and there's every reason to believe Toy Story is going to be a good movie property. So if I've gone beyond that, I apologize and I reprimand myself and we won't do it again. But obviously, Toy Story should be a really important property. It's been a great property for the last 10 years without entertainment support, and everything I've heard about the movie is it's going to be a terrific movie. So it's obviously going to be bigger than the bread basket.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gerrick Johnson from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gerrick Johnson from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk about Fisher-Price and provide some sort of organic growth number for Fisher-Price exclusive of the Thomas shipments?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about Fisher-Price and provide some sort of organic growth number for Fisher-Price exclusive of the Thomas shipments?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think Fisher-Price, Gerrick, is one of the areas that's a really good example of retailers this year needing to buy what they sold as compared to last year. Last year, in the first quarter, retailers didn't need to buy that much from us in order t
componenttext: Well, I think Fisher-Price, Gerrick, is one of the areas that's a really good example of retailers this year needing to buy what they sold as compared to last year. Last year, in the first quarter, retailers didn't need to buy that much from us in order to support the POS that they had. This year, they had to do that. And I think Fisher-Price is probably the most shining example of that. There's certainly some areas in core toys that are doing well. But the momentum on Fisher-Price is, right now, more consistent with the fourth quarter or the holiday season in the POS and the Fisher-Price than we expected to be later this year. We've made some changes to the key drivers of the line in terms of the innovations that we have and the price points that we'll be offering. So I think, right now, the Fisher-Price success from the first quarter is really more related to what retailers needed to do than the POS trends.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't break it out with respect to each of the businesses, excluding the entertainment. But if you look at Fisher-Price Core globally, it was up 5%, which would exclude Thomas, as well as if you look at it domestically, it was up 2%. And in internation
componenttext: We don't break it out with respect to each of the businesses, excluding the entertainment. But if you look at Fisher-Price Core globally, it was up 5%, which would exclude Thomas, as well as if you look at it domestically, it was up 2%. And in international, it was up -- Core was up 10%.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, but Core hasn't been the problem, it's been Friends. So I'm kind of wondering how that number looked exclusive of Thomas?
componenttext: Yes, but Core hasn't been the problem, it's been Friends. So I'm kind of wondering how that number looked exclusive of Thomas?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that just Friends has been an issue, I think we've had some issues on Core as well. But within Friends, Dora did very nicely this quarter. We've seen some increases in Dora, we've seen increases in Disney, in the Fisher-Price line, in t
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that just Friends has been an issue, I think we've had some issues on Core as well. But within Friends, Dora did very nicely this quarter. We've seen some increases in Dora, we've seen increases in Disney, in the Fisher-Price line, in the Friends line, and we've seen some decreases in Sesame Street which is consistent with the trend. So some of the things like Dora that has been a drag on our sales potential, certainly, from a point of sales standpoint, actually, we've seen better success on Dora of late than we have for some time.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Bob, it sounds like you've been in the stores a lot lately. I was wondering if you could perhaps comment on any sort of industry trends you're seeing, category trends to the Fashion business, where are kids gravitating this days? And I'm particularly
componenttext: And, Bob, it sounds like you've been in the stores a lot lately. I was wondering if you could perhaps comment on any sort of industry trends you're seeing, category trends to the Fashion business, where are kids gravitating this days? And I'm particularly interested in the Girls segment, fashion dolls versus mini dolls, et cetera?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think toys, in general, have held up pretty well in the holiday season last year just as they did for the past five or six recessions. And I think there's pretty good momentum relative to other categories in the Toy business right now. And I don't know
componenttext: I think toys, in general, have held up pretty well in the holiday season last year just as they did for the past five or six recessions. And I think there's pretty good momentum relative to other categories in the Toy business right now. And I don't know that that's going to change. We're certainly seeing good momentum in our Girls business. We tend to be the leaders in things Girls. So I think that bodes well for what's happening in the marketplace.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And lastly, discount retailers, are there any changes on the way they do business that may be benefiting the industry and Mattel this year? We often talk about what they're doing that's detrimental to the industry, but what might they'll be doing this yea
componenttext: And lastly, discount retailers, are there any changes on the way they do business that may be benefiting the industry and Mattel this year? We often talk about what they're doing that's detrimental to the industry, but what might they'll be doing this year that might benefit you guys?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that there's significant change in the retail landscape that I've seen.
componenttext: I don't know that there's significant change in the retail landscape that I've seen.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Linda Bolton Weiser of Caris.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Linda Bolton Weiser of Caris.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk a little bit more about that retail inventory situation? And I'm trying to gauge how many more quarters you could actually have shipments exceed the POS growth. Was it second quarter or more like third quarter last year where the retaile
componenttext: Can you just talk a little bit more about that retail inventory situation? And I'm trying to gauge how many more quarters you could actually have shipments exceed the POS growth. Was it second quarter or more like third quarter last year where the retailers started to behave a little more normally on the inventory front?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: My recollection from last year, Linda, is that inventories, as we calculate them, that is retail inventories based on what we ship in and what POS sold, declined every quarter last year compared to the prior year. And this year, in the first quarter, we a
componenttext: My recollection from last year, Linda, is that inventories, as we calculate them, that is retail inventories based on what we ship in and what POS sold, declined every quarter last year compared to the prior year. And this year, in the first quarter, we are seeing retail inventories down versus the prior year. So I don't think there's been a change in trend. And again, as I tried to mention earlier, I'm not really betting on a big change in trend, I think retailers are going to continue to focus on inventory management.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: But certainly, your shipments can't exceed POS for many more quarters. So is it one more quarter, two more quarters before the math works out that the retail inventories year-over-year are more normalized? Do you understand what I'm asking?
componenttext: But certainly, your shipments can't exceed POS for many more quarters. So is it one more quarter, two more quarters before the math works out that the retail inventories year-over-year are more normalized? Do you understand what I'm asking?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I understand what you're asking, I'm not sure that I can answer the question. The changes on a percentage basis are consistent with having different basis. What we really saw in the first quarter that I've tried to communicate is retailers bought
componenttext: I guess I understand what you're asking, I'm not sure that I can answer the question. The changes on a percentage basis are consistent with having different basis. What we really saw in the first quarter that I've tried to communicate is retailers bought what they sold. So the percentage change on shipments is a function of what they bought last year. But today, they're currently buying what they're selling.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the pricing, can you just remind us, is the pricing that you mentioned that favorably contributed gross margin, is that a carryover from actions taken in '09, or was that like new pricing initiatives in early 2010?
componenttext: And then on the pricing, can you just remind us, is the pricing that you mentioned that favorably contributed gross margin, is that a carryover from actions taken in '09, or was that like new pricing initiatives in early 2010?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's primarily a carryover, Linda.
componenttext: It's primarily a carryover, Linda.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can you remind us again, was there two rounds of pricing in '09? I mean, what's the thought in 2010?
componenttext: And can you remind us again, was there two rounds of pricing in '09? I mean, what's the thought in 2010?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, there was one round of pricing, generally speaking, in '09. There will be one round of pricing in 2010. We did not price significantly in 2010, but we did price, and it's consistent with what we had planned on the input cost being at the time.
componenttext: No, there was one round of pricing, generally speaking, in '09. There will be one round of pricing in 2010. We did not price significantly in 2010, but we did price, and it's consistent with what we had planned on the input cost being at the time.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then this time, your Global Cost Leadership, I mean, you've been really successful with that so far and you'll be realizing the final savings this year. Are you thinking about initiating a new program or focusing in other areas or continuing it? And m
componenttext: And then this time, your Global Cost Leadership, I mean, you've been really successful with that so far and you'll be realizing the final savings this year. Are you thinking about initiating a new program or focusing in other areas or continuing it? And might we hear more about details on that at the Analyst Meeting?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think from the perspective of the Global Cost Leadership Program, I think we are executing it, I think we are on track to deliver the $180 million to $200 million. I think as part of this program, we're really trying to infuse our culture with thi
componenttext: Well, I think from the perspective of the Global Cost Leadership Program, I think we are executing it, I think we are on track to deliver the $180 million to $200 million. I think as part of this program, we're really trying to infuse our culture with this continuous improvement philosophy. And I think, like we have in the past, we'll continue to look for opportunities to be more efficient and effective and drive cost-savings programs. Whether that will be a formal program or an informal program, we'll continue to look at what makes sense.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Hayley Wolff of Rochdale Securities.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Hayley Wolff of Rochdale Securities.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just following up on Linda's question, the cost saving potential in 2011, I mean, Kevin earlier talked about SKU reduction starting to benefit you in 2011. And now that you're running your business a lot smarter, a lot more efficiently, we should b
componenttext: First, just following up on Linda's question, the cost saving potential in 2011, I mean, Kevin earlier talked about SKU reduction starting to benefit you in 2011. And now that you're running your business a lot smarter, a lot more efficiently, we should be able to expect some cost savings.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we should expect cost savings from SKU rationalization. We did see some of that in '09. We expect to see more of it in '10. And we expect to deliver even more in 2011.
componenttext: Yes, we should expect cost savings from SKU rationalization. We did see some of that in '09. We expect to see more of it in '10. And we expect to deliver even more in 2011.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, order of magnitude relative to GCL, can you comment on that?
componenttext: I mean, order of magnitude relative to GCL, can you comment on that?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to give the specific details, but the '10 savings are within the $180 million to $200 million cumulative goal that we have for 2010.
componenttext: I'm not going to give the specific details, but the '10 savings are within the $180 million to $200 million cumulative goal that we have for 2010.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: But you won't give us a sense relative to what '11 could have relative to '10 from some of these initiative in place now?
componenttext: But you won't give us a sense relative to what '11 could have relative to '10 from some of these initiative in place now?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not trying to be difficult, but it is a pretty difficult thing to estimate because it touches the entire value chain.
componenttext: Yes, I'm not trying to be difficult, but it is a pretty difficult thing to estimate because it touches the entire value chain.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then American Girl, the Denver store, did that benefit you in the first quarter, or is that a second quarter?
componenttext: And then American Girl, the Denver store, did that benefit you in the first quarter, or is that a second quarter?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: More second quarter, Hayley. It did open in the first quarter, and we're continuing to look at expansion opportunities for American Girl. It's our smallest store, it's under 10,000 square feet. It's kind of a test of the new smaller store that it doesn't
componenttext: More second quarter, Hayley. It did open in the first quarter, and we're continuing to look at expansion opportunities for American Girl. It's our smallest store, it's under 10,000 square feet. It's kind of a test of the new smaller store that it doesn't have any food service involved. But it did not have a big impact on the first quarter. Remember, what we sell at retail is what gets counted in numbers on American Girl, and it's really only been opened a couple of weeks.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And there's been some talk about a re-release of Avatar in September, I think, or sometime during the fall. Do you have any comments on that and. . .
componenttext: And there's been some talk about a re-release of Avatar in September, I think, or sometime during the fall. Do you have any comments on that and. . .

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Avatar is a focused product line. It's a terrific movie. The DVD, I think, comes out in a couple of weeks here or maybe even next week. It is not a big driver of our performance. It's not a big toy property. That's what we thought when we went into the de
componenttext: Avatar is a focused product line. It's a terrific movie. The DVD, I think, comes out in a couple of weeks here or maybe even next week. It is not a big driver of our performance. It's not a big toy property. That's what we thought when we went into the development of the line and that's exactly how it's played out. So Avatar is not going to be a big contributor this year. Again, when I visit stores, there's plenty of Avatar product out there, it's good product, it tells the story well, but it's just not going to be a big entertainment property for the Toy business.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you comment on any legal expenses for the Bratz litigation and how we should think about them throughout the course of this year?
componenttext: Can you comment on any legal expenses for the Bratz litigation and how we should think about them throughout the course of this year?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, as you know, we've been incurring significant legal costs over the last couple of years related to MGA and recall-related litigation. For full year 2008, we incurred incremental legal costs of about $37 million, related primarily to Phase I
componenttext: Yes. I think, as you know, we've been incurring significant legal costs over the last couple of years related to MGA and recall-related litigation. For full year 2008, we incurred incremental legal costs of about $37 million, related primarily to Phase I in the MGA trial which occurred in May through July of 2008. For 2009, litigation-related legal costs decreased by  $33 million. Additionally, in the first quarter of 2009, we recorded $21 million in charges related to a legal settlement for product liability-related litigation. The good news is, going forward, we expect legal fees related to recall-related litigation to be relatively minor, given the recent legal settlement for product liability litigation. And as Bob said, and as you know, we're still in litigation with MGA and the current legal costs associated with the case being reviewed by the Court of Appeals. In addition, we're also incurring legal fees as we prepare for the next MGA trial, which could occur in 2010. While we reduced expenses in 2009, we'll continue to make the appropriate level of investments in legal fees until the legal matters are resolved. And if you look at Q1, legal costs are up $6 million in Q1 versus the prior year.
