headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Mattel's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce, Ms. Dianne Douglas. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Mattel's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce, Ms. Dianne Douglas. Please go ahead.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary. As you know, this morning, we reported Mattel's Second Quarter 2010 Financial Results. In a few minutes, Bob Eckert, Mattel's Chairman and CEO; and Kevin Farr, Mattel's CFO, will provide comments on the results, and then the call will be
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary. As you know, this morning, we reported Mattel's Second Quarter 2010 Financial Results. In a few minutes, Bob Eckert, Mattel's Chairman and CEO; and Kevin Farr, Mattel's CFO, will provide comments on the results, and then the call will be opened for your questions.  
Certain statements Bob and Kevin make during the call may include forward-looking statements relating to the future performance of our overall business, brands and product lines. These statements are based on currently available operating, financial, economic and competitive information, and they are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, which could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. 
We describe some of these uncertainties in the Risk Factors section of our 2009 Annual Report on Form 10-K, as well as in our quarterly report on Form 10-Q and in other filings we make with the SEC from time to time.  Mattel does not update forward-looking statements and expressly disclaims any obligation to do so. 
Information required by Regulation G regarding non-GAAP financial measures is available on the Investors and Media section of our corporate website, mattel.com, under the subheading, Financial Information and Earnings Releases. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Bob.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dianne, and good morning, everyone. What a difference a year makes. Last year at this time, Mattel, along with many other consumer goods companies and retailers, was lamenting how much further the economy was going to decline. And while reports
componenttext:
Thank you, Dianne, and good morning, everyone. What a difference a year makes. Last year at this time, Mattel, along with many other consumer goods companies and retailers, was lamenting how much further the economy was going to decline. And while reports remain mixed on whether or not we're out of the woods, I can tell you that I'm very pleased with the company's performance for the quarter, with worldwide net sales of 13%, reflecting good performance in the U.S., as well as internationally and continued improvement in our profit margins. 
Our positive top line sales trend this quarter, in both the U.S. and abroad, benefited from our newest entertainment properties, Toy Story 3, World Wrestling Entertainment and Thomas and Friends, as well as solid growth from core brands such as Barbie and Hot Wheels. 
As it relates to Barbie, the core fashion, beach and accessory product lines continue to perform well. At our spring entertainment offering, Barbie, A Mermaid Tale, nicely outperformed last year's movie. Our icon B line, driven by a very strong spring promotional program, continues to perform well at retail. And I'm proud to report that the Barbie leadership team hasn't missed a beat, and is continuing to drive the brand to deliver on fashion, aspiration and cultural relevance. 
I know there's a lot of interest in the launch of our Monster High franchise, which has just began. We know girls are becoming engaged with the brand, as evidenced by the millions of Monster High episodes downloaded from the website. 
The Justice Apparel program is just growing up to more than 900 stores nationwide, and the Monsters will be taking over YouTube's homepage this summer, with an all-new Monster High music video. Toy advertising begins around the back-to-school timeframe, which also coincides with sales of the first Little, Brown hardback, chapter book, which hits retail in September.
In the Wheels item. Hot Wheels performance has been solid, driven by both core play, with basic cars and track sets, as well as the feature product lines, like Custom Motors and Color Shifters, and we're excited about the Matchbox launch of Stinky the Garbage Truck, following on the successful launch of Rocky the Robot Truck last year. These characters are now part of the new Big Rig Buddies line, which we're introducing to kids this fall via CGI-animated episodes, being packed with the products.
And of course, there's the incredible success of this year's summer movie, Toy Story 3. Not surprisingly, our Toy Story 3 lines are selling well across all businesses including infant and preschool, action figures, collectibles, playsets, vehicles, role play, Barbie and Ken dolls and games. And now that Spain has taken on the World Cup title, the movie will be hitting theaters in key European markets. 
In the World Wrestling. WWE sales continue to be strong, driven not only by our core line that appeals to collectors, but by the FlexForce toys, which are more kid-focused and feature-driven. As I said before, what's most exciting about our newest licensed properties is that we expect them to perform work into Evergreen toy brands than one-hit wonders, which augur well for our business, not only in 2010, but beyond.
In the infant & preschool aisle. Our Fisher-Price Friends business performed quite well, with Dora the Explorer, rebounding nicely, and of course, the addition of Thomas and Friends. We're also looking forward to Dora's 10-year anniversary, which Nickelodeon is kicking off this fall. 
This summer, American Girl launched the Shine On Now program, a new charitable initiative that harnesses the collective power of girls to help others in need. To further encourage and inspire girls, American Girl is also launching a brand-new virtual campus, Innerstar University, a fun, safe website for girls. Access to the new virtual world comes with each 18-inch, My American Girl doll, the new company's newly enhanced contemporary product line, which is currently available. 
From our time-honored brands to our newest entertainment partners, I'm encouraged by the strong momentum in the first half of the year, as we begin to count down to the all-important holiday season. We remain committed to maximizing long term value for our shareholders. As you know, we're focused on controlling costs and effectively deploying capital. 
Over the last seven years, we have repurchased about 114 million shares of our stock, with a total cost of $2.2 billion, including repurchasing about 5 million shares this quarter, and it distributed $1.6 billion in dividends. Effective capital deployment, combined with solid top line growth and improving margins, will allow us to win in the marketplace and for our shareholders. 
At this time, I'd like to introduce Mattel's Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Farr, who will take you through a financial review of the quarter. Kevin?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob, and good morning, everyone. I'll begin my review for the second quarter with a discussion of worldwide gross sales shown on Exhibit 2 of today's press release. Total worldwide gross sales for the quarter were up 13%, including a three-pe
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob, and good morning, everyone. I'll begin my review for the second quarter with a discussion of worldwide gross sales shown on Exhibit 2 of today's press release. 
Total worldwide gross sales for the quarter were up 13%, including a three-percentage-point negative impact and changes in exchange rates. U.S. sales were up 17%. International sales were up 9%, including a five-percentage-point negative impact from foreign exchange. 
On a retail basis, sales in Europe were up 7%, including a seven-percentage-point negative impact from exchange rates. Sales in Latin America were up 1%, including a 10 percentage point negative impact on foreign exchange, and sales in Asia-Pacific were up 28%, including a six-percentage-point positive impact from changes in exchange rates. 
I will now review our core business and brands for the second quarter. Mattel Girls & Boys Brands. Worldwide sales from Mattel Girls & Boys Brands segment were up 21%, including a three-percentage point negative impact from changes in exchange rates. On a retail basis, domestic sales were up 37% and international sales were up 11%, including a five-percentage-point negative impact from changes in exchange rates. 
Worldwide Barbie sales were up 6%, including a four-percentage-point negative impact from foreign exchange. Barbie sales in the U.S. were up 16%, while Barbie sales in the international markets were up 1%, including a six-percentage-point negative impact from foreign exchange. 
Worldwide sales at Other Girls Brands were up 3%, including a three-percentage-point negative impact from exchange rates. Continued good growth in Disney Princesses was partially offset by international declines in High School Musical, Hannah Montana and Polly Pocket. Sales of Other Girls Brands in the U.S. were up 15%, and international sales were down 7%, including a five-percentage-point negative impact from foreign exchange. 
Worldwide sales of Wheels increased 5%, including a two-percentage-point negative impact from changes in currency exchange rates. The growth in Wheels was led by strong worldwide sales of Hot Wheels. Hot Wheels increased 11% worldwide, including zero impact from foreign exchange. Hot Wheels sales increased 19% in U.S., and were up 5% internationally, including a one-percentage point negative impact from foreign exchange. 
Worldwide sales in our Entertainment business, which included Games and Puzzles, was up 60%, including a five-percentage-point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange. Sales were up 90% in the U.S. and up 40% internationally, including an eight-percentage-point negative impact from changes in foreign exchange. 
Sales increases were primarily driven by our new Toy Story 3 products and continued momentum from other new Entertainment properties, WWE Wrestling, as well as good growth in our Core Games business. 
Fisher-Price Brands. Worldwide sales of Fisher-Price brands were up 4%, including a two-percentage-point negative impact from changes in currency rates. On a regional basis, domestic sales of Fisher-Price Brands increased 4% and international sales increased 5%, including a five-percentage-point negative impact from foreign exchange. 
Worldwide Core Fisher-Price was flat, including a two-percentage point negative impact from changes in exchange rates. International sales were up 1%, including a five-percentage-point negative impact from foreign exchange, and U.S. sales of Fisher-Price Core were down 1%. Fisher-Price Brands worldwide sales increased 35%, including a five-percentage-point negative impact from foreign exchange rates. 
International sales were up 25%, including a 10 percentage point negative impact from foreign exchange, while sales of Fisher-Price Friends in the U.S. were up 45%. The growth of Fisher-Price Friends is driven primarily by the addition of products supporting a new Thomas and Friends property, as well as growth in Dora the Explorer and Disney products. 
American Girl Brands. Sales of American Girl Brands were down 4%, primarily the result of last year's second quarter launch of Rebecca, and a slightly earlier Easter this year, partially offset by continued strong sales of Lanie, the 2010 Girl of the Year and good performance from our new Denver store.
Now let's review the P&L, which is shown on Exhibit 1. Gross margin was 48.1% compared to 45.2% last year. The improvement was primarily due to lower product costs, price increases and savings from our Global Cost Leadership initiatives, partially offset by higher royalties. We continue to expect input comp pressures in our gross margin beginning in the second half of this year, given the current commodity and labor costs environments relative to year-ago levels. Advertising expense was $101.9 million or 10% of net sales compared to $89.8 million, or 10% of net sales in 2009. 
Selling, general and administrative  expenses increased approximately $34.5 million to $318.3 million. As a percentage of net sales, SG&A expenses were 31.3% compared to 31.6% last year. The year-to-year dollar increase primarily reflects increased legal-related costs, and employee-related costs, including incentive accruals and merit increases, as well as severance costs, partially offset by savings related to our Global Cost Leadership program. 
For the first half of the year, SG&A expenses are up $10 million or 2%, and represent 32.2% of net sales compared with 35.7% for the first half of 2009. For the quarter, our Global Cost Leadership program delivered overall gross savings before severance of about $12 million. The gross savings includes about $4 million in SG&A, $5 million in gross margin and $3 million in advertising. 
For the quarter, we recorded severance charges of $9 million. The net year-over-year incremental savings related to the Global Cost Leadership program is about $3 million for the quarter. We remain on track to deliver cumulative net savings at the high end of the target range for the program of $180 million to $200 million by the end of 2010. 
Operating income during the quarter was $69.4 million compared to $32.5 million in 2009. The year-to-year improvement was primarily due to higher sales and gross margins, partially offset by higher SG&A and advertising expense. 
Interest expense of $13.4 million was down from $17.5 million last year, reflecting lower average borrowings, as well as lower average interest rates. Interest income was $2.8 million versus $2.5 million last year. The higher interest income was due to higher average invested cash balances during the quarter. 
Other non-operating income was $3.3 million during the quarter versus $6.3 million in 2009. The income in both period relates primarily to foreign currency exchange gains. The quarter's income tax provision of $10.5 million includes discrete tax benefits of $4.6 million. This compares to prior year's provision of $2.3 million, which included discrete tax benefits of $2.5 million. 
For the year, we continue to expect the worldwide effective tax rate to be about 24% to 25%, based on current tax laws. Overall, we reported net income of $51.6 million or $0.14 per share versus last year's net income of $21.5 million or $0.06 per share.
Now turning to the cash flow and balance sheet. Year-to-date cash flow used for operations was $372 million compared to $350 million in the first half of 2009. Our cash on hand at the end of the quarter was $545 million, up $122 million from prior year. The increase in cash is primarily due to higher beginning cash balances of $1.1 billion this year versus $618 million last year, partially offset primarily by a lack of short-term borrowings and capital deployment. 
During the second quarter, the company repurchased approximately 5 million of its shares of common stock at an average price of $22.05 per share, for a total cost of approximately $111 million. I'm pleased with our management of working capital, especially in light of 13% growth in the business. 
Receivables were $805 million or 71 days of sales outstanding, four days lower than last year. Factoring decreased from $81 million to 0. Prior to factoring, days of sales outstanding decreased 12 days. During the first half of 2010, we made a decision not to factor receivables due to our current cash position and availability of lower-cost funding alternatives. 
Inventories at $598 million were up $8 million or 1% versus 2009. Our total balance sheet debt was $710 million, a decrease of $344 million from the prior year, reflecting the lack of short-term borrowings and the paydown in maturing long-term notes. Our debt to total capital ratio ended the quarter at 22.1% versus 32.7% for last year's second quarter. Capital expenditures were $33.4 million, down from last year's $41.7 million.
So to summarize, we are pleased with this quarter's results. But there's a lot of work to be done between now and year end to deliver on our priorities: Continued core brand momentum, maximize the opportunities surrounding our new entertainment properties, maintain cost and expense controls and deliver another strong year of profits and cash flow. 
That concludes my review of the financial results. Now we'd like to open the call to questions. Operator?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Linda Bolton Weiser from Caris.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just elaborate a little bit more on the Other Girls sales performance? Because that was really strong in the first quarter and I know FX is a little bit more negative. But is it a Polly Pocket decline or some other decline got a lot worse or exact
componenttext: Can you just elaborate a little bit more on the Other Girls sales performance? Because that was really strong in the first quarter and I know FX is a little bit more negative. But is it a Polly Pocket decline or some other decline got a lot worse or exactly what? And then my second question would be just on incentive compensation accruals. I know you don't like to disclose a lot, but can you give, maybe year-to-date or something, what the dollar increase in compensation accruals is for the first half versus first half of '09, like how much of the delta increases year-over-year?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Linda, it's Bob. I'll start with Other Girls, then Kevin can talk about the incentive accrual. I think at constant dollars, our Other Girls business was up 6% in the quarter, maybe it was 3% in actual dollars. So there was a little bit of ForEx. And we ge
componenttext: Linda, it's Bob. I'll start with Other Girls, then Kevin can talk about the incentive accrual. I think at constant dollars, our Other Girls business was up 6% in the quarter, maybe it was 3% in actual dollars. So there was a little bit of ForEx. And we generally have pretty good trends in the Other Girls business. Clearly, Disney Princess continues to have very strong momentum, and we are excited about this fall's movie, Tangle Movie, which is the story of Rapunzel. Monster High is in the Other Girls segment. It is a various small business in the second quarter, but obviously, we're quite hopeful on that. Polly is seeing improved results more recently in the U.S., including during the quarter, but we still have some work to do internationally with Polly. And we're also facing some declines from the prior year and things like High School Musical and Hannah Montana, which we distribute outside of the U.S. So it's a portfolio of brands, generally speaking, more continue to do well than that if they cycle through.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the incentive compensation, we don't disclose the quarterly detail for incentive comp. You may recall that given the seasonality of our business, the vast majority of accrued incentive compensation is recorded in the second half of the year, d
componenttext: And then on the incentive compensation, we don't disclose the quarterly detail for incentive comp. You may recall that given the seasonality of our business, the vast majority of accrued incentive compensation is recorded in the second half of the year, driven primarily by the achievement of our annual performance goals in the key season. That being said, accounting rules require a higher accrual in the second quarter versus last year due to year-to-date performance improvements, and maybe I'll take the opportunity as a result of the question, really, to get into the SG&A increase for the quarter. For the quarter, SG&A expenses increased approximately $35 million to $318 million. As a percentage of sales, SG&A expense was 31.3% or down 30 basis points compared to the prior year. The year-over-year dollar increase primarily reflects $12 million of legal-related costs, $16 million of employee-related costs and $7 million of incremental severance, which was partially offset by approximately $5 million of gross savings related to the Global Cost Leadership program. About 1/3 of the higher employee-related costs was due to merit increases affected in March and the other 2/3 was due to the timing of incentive accruals. And as I said that, due to the seasonality, really most of the incentive compensation is accrued in the second half, but as I said, the accounting rules require us is -- our performance was better. We accrued more in the second quarter versus last year. In the second quarter of 2010, we incurred higher incentive costs of $9 million versus $2 million in the prior year related to Global Cost Leadership program. So it's $9 million of severance in the second quarter versus $2 million last year.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we probably won't get that granular, but I can tell you that the, kind of, the core fashion and beauty and the aspiration of the Icon B segments, the spring entertainment, they continue to perform well. Barbie's continuing to gain share. We have goo
componenttext: Well, we probably won't get that granular, but I can tell you that the, kind of, the core fashion and beauty and the aspiration of the Icon B segments, the spring entertainment, they continue to perform well. Barbie's continuing to gain share. We have good plans in place to carry the momentum through the holiday, like the Video Girl Barbie, and we're seeing improved momentum outside of the U.S. So for those of you saw who saw the Toy Story 3 movie, clearly, Barbie and Ken stole the show. And not surprisingly, those dolls are selling well, but we're seeing continued good momentum around the globe in Barbie POS.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Another question -- I don't know if it's for you or Kevin, but on the legal expenses, and I assume that's being driven by your friends up north, it's a little further north. Can you give us an update on what's going on there?
componenttext: Another question -- I don't know if it's for you or Kevin, but on the legal expenses, and I assume that's being driven by your friends up north, it's a little further north. Can you give us an update on what's going on there?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start and, Kevin, if you want to chime in, feel free. If you recall back in December, the Ninth Circuit Court heard arguments surrounding the trial court's orders from the Phase 1 of the case, which had resulted in a unanimous jury verdict in
componenttext: Yes, let me start and, Kevin, if you want to chime in, feel free. If you recall back in December, the Ninth Circuit Court heard arguments surrounding the trial court's orders from the Phase 1 of the case, which had resulted in a unanimous jury verdict in favor of Mattel. The court hasn't yet issued any opinion on that. So nothing's changed from that front, but you will recall they did issue an order stating the equitable relief, which included the transfer of the Bratz's copyright registrations and trademarks to Mattel. So there's nothing new on Phase 1 of the case other than we're still awaiting the circuit court's opinion. We're now moving forward with Phase 2 of the case at the district court level. That's the phase that alleges, among other things, that MGA systematically stole Mattel's trade secrets, and there hasn't been a trial date set yet for Phase 2. So overall, I'd say we continue to have faith in the judicial systems and confidence in our claims and the evidence, just as we did in Phase 1, and we'll pursue this as long as we need to.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: So it's really Phase 2 then that's driving a $12 million increase in that spending?
componenttext: So it's really Phase 2 then that's driving a $12 million increase in that spending?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's virtually all Phase 2, as we're preparing for trial, and we're ready to go anytime the court is ready to start the trial.
componenttext: Yes, it's virtually all Phase 2, as we're preparing for trial, and we're ready to go anytime the court is ready to start the trial.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little bit more clarity, Sean, on sort of, our legal fees and settlements have impacted the first quarter and the first half results. In the second quarter of 2010, we incurred incremental legal fees of approximately $8 million, primaril
componenttext: Let me give you a little bit more clarity, Sean, on sort of, our legal fees and settlements have impacted the first quarter and the first half results. In the second quarter of 2010, we incurred incremental legal fees of approximately $8 million, primarily related to preparing for Phase 2 of the MGA trial, which could occur in 2010. If you look at the first half of 2010, we incurred incremental legal fees of approximately $14 million, again, primarily related to brand from Phase 2 of the MGA trial. And then moving on to settlements, legal settlements related to recall. If you remember in the first quarter of 2009, we took a $21 million charge for a legal settlement reserved for product liability related to litigation. And then in the second quarter of 2009, we adjusted this charge down by $5 million, primarily due to insurance recovery. So the first half of 2010, we reversed $9 million of the recall-related charges to reflect the action settlement amounts approved by the court in 2010. So altogether for the first half of 2010, the total year-over-year improvement pertaining to the 2009 recall-related legal settlement was $25 million. And if you look at both legal fees and legal settlements, for the first half of 2010, we incurred incremental legal fees of $14 million, primarily related to MGA. These incremental fees were more than offset by the year-to-date favorable change in recall settlement charges of $25 million.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Carroll from UBS.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you might be able to comment on the progression during the quarter. I mean, given the timeline of the release around Toy Story 3, are you guys able to comment if there was kind of a ground swell after the movie for the Barbie and Ken products
componenttext: I was hoping you might be able to comment on the progression during the quarter. I mean, given the timeline of the release around Toy Story 3, are you guys able to comment if there was kind of a ground swell after the movie for the Barbie and Ken products, as well as just kind of Toy Story 3 in general?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, I'd say overall, the momentum built not surprisingly. We had pretty good sales early in the quarter as retailers were gearing up for Toy Story 3, and then POS did very well for Toy Story 3. But I'd also tell you that the POS momentum was mor
componenttext: Yes. I guess, I'd say overall, the momentum built not surprisingly. We had pretty good sales early in the quarter as retailers were gearing up for Toy Story 3, and then POS did very well for Toy Story 3. But I'd also tell you that the POS momentum was more broadly based than just Toy Story. If you look at the quarterly flow of the point of sale, clearly, the momentum is picking up broadly around the globe. Today, I'm probably more concerned about supply than demand. In China, we see labor supply tightening, the rates are up, shipping containers are in short supply, freight's taking longer to move than it sometimes does. In Mexico, there was a hurricane near one our of our facilities in Monterrey and there's been floods from essentially, Monterrey to Laredo, Texas. So all of these was occurring while our business was picking up and orders were strong. The good news is we have a long history of overcoming supply chain obstacles like this. So as always, we're continuing to focus on getting the right toys at the right place at the right time. But I think right now and then certainly in the near term, in my view, the supply chain is relatively more important than POS momentum, which continues to be quite strong.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: But then focusing just on Barbie, I mean given that, I guess, Barbie's role in the movie was probably a little more prominent than many people expected going in. Was there a pronounced uptick in kind of Barbie POS given the last couple of weeks in the qua
componenttext: But then focusing just on Barbie, I mean given that, I guess, Barbie's role in the movie was probably a little more prominent than many people expected going in. Was there a pronounced uptick in kind of Barbie POS given the last couple of weeks in the quarter?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say POS has been strong fairly consistently for over a year at Barbie. Obviously, week-to-week it does change a little bit. But we've seen good momentum before the Toy Story 3 products hit. We clearly saw a good success for the Toy Story 3 products, w
componenttext: I'd say POS has been strong fairly consistently for over a year at Barbie. Obviously, week-to-week it does change a little bit. But we've seen good momentum before the Toy Story 3 products hit. We clearly saw a good success for the Toy Story 3 products, which wasn't surprise. We've had pretty good stock on those products. So I would say there's no question that the Toy Story 3, Barbie and Ken had done well. But there's broad-based strength across the line, and Barbie POS momentum has looked good even in markets where Toy Story 3 has yet to air.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Crum from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, could you comment a little further on Toy Story 3 overseas? I think you alluded to the fact that the sale has been delayed in order to avoid the competition from the World Cup. Can you talk about the opportunities you see there in terms of selling, g
componenttext: Bob, could you comment a little further on Toy Story 3 overseas? I think you alluded to the fact that the sale has been delayed in order to avoid the competition from the World Cup. Can you talk about the opportunities you see there in terms of selling, given the delay in the film release?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: There is no question Toy Story 3 has been a home run, broadly speaking, not just for our product line, but I'm sure for others in the Toy business, Toy Story 3 licenses or for other categories in consumer products. The movie, as you all know, did very, ve
componenttext: There is no question Toy Story 3 has been a home run, broadly speaking, not just for our product line, but I'm sure for others in the Toy business, Toy Story 3 licenses or for other categories in consumer products. The movie, as you all know, did very, very well. From our vantage point, it's an incredibly toy addict movie and the business has done well in response to the movie and in response to retailers' promotions surrounding the movie. I think there's some key European markets that aired the movie in July. I believe by the end of July, all the key European markets: Italy, France, Germany, Spain will have aired the movie. And I don't have any reason to believe it won't be a homerun outside the U.S. as well. So I think we're ready for it. The inventory is in place, retail and promotions are set up, and I would not be surprised if it does well outside of the U.S. like it has done well in the U.S.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Does the timing of the film release impacted the timing of your selling for the product overseas? Is there more in the third quarter or is that pretty balanced in the second quarter domestic versus international?
componenttext: Does the timing of the film release impacted the timing of your selling for the product overseas? Is there more in the third quarter or is that pretty balanced in the second quarter domestic versus international?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: More balanced than that, and it really didn't affect -- the timing of the movie has not affected our shipment calendar in the process.
componenttext: More balanced than that, and it really didn't affect -- the timing of the movie has not affected our shipment calendar in the process.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just shifting gears, the Thomas and Friends, during our channel checks we still see a lot of legacy products from the predecessor licensee. Are you seeing that in your results? And at what point do you think that corrects itself?
componenttext: And then just shifting gears, the Thomas and Friends, during our channel checks we still see a lot of legacy products from the predecessor licensee. Are you seeing that in your results? And at what point do you think that corrects itself?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're pretty close on that. There's just enough stories that I am starting to see our product appear particularly in the Diecast segment. So I think we finally cycled through the sell-off period from someone else's product line. And generally spea
componenttext: I think we're pretty close on that. There's just enough stories that I am starting to see our product appear particularly in the Diecast segment. So I think we finally cycled through the sell-off period from someone else's product line. And generally speaking, some of our products were a little slower to come through the pipeline than we expected, but the business is doing well and is tracking everywhere where we thought it would be.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And Kevin, a question for you. The advertising spend as a percentage of the revenue, 10% in the quarter. I think you're below the historical average of the percentage of revenue. Where do you see that going in the balance of the year? Or can you give us a
componenttext: And Kevin, a question for you. The advertising spend as a percentage of the revenue, 10% in the quarter. I think you're below the historical average of the percentage of revenue. Where do you see that going in the balance of the year? Or can you give us an update as far as your thoughts are concerned for 2010?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, the advertising expense as a percentage of the sales for the quarter is consistent with last year. And I think in 2009, our advertising expense is 11.2% of net sales, which was on the low end of our historical range reflecting the benefit of
componenttext: Yes, I think, the advertising expense as a percentage of the sales for the quarter is consistent with last year. And I think in 2009, our advertising expense is 11.2% of net sales, which was on the low end of our historical range reflecting the benefit of GCL initiatives, which was a challenging environment. Our rate has historically been in 11% to 13% range, and we expect to be at the lower end of the range in 2010.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just last question, housekeeping item. You got $250 million of long-term debt classified as short term. Now can you just give us a sense as of the timing of those repayments?
componenttext: And then just last question, housekeeping item. You got $250 million of long-term debt classified as short term. Now can you just give us a sense as of the timing of those repayments?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think they become due next year. They're actually due next year in June, $240 million of the $250 million, and $10 million of it is actually due this fall in October.
componenttext: Yes, I think they become due next year. They're actually due next year in June, $240 million of the $250 million, and $10 million of it is actually due this fall in October.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Taylor from Arcadia Investment.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Taylor from Arcadia Investment.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: So in the way the order book looks for Toy Story 3 in the U.S., I guess, I want to focus on -- do you see anything different about the pacing of the way retailers want to bring that product in that might be different from what you've seen with entertainme
componenttext: So in the way the order book looks for Toy Story 3 in the U.S., I guess, I want to focus on -- do you see anything different about the pacing of the way retailers want to bring that product in that might be different from what you've seen with entertainment properties, and some are entertainment properties in the past. Do you have any forward, backward weight at anything that is different from the norm?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: No, J.T., I wouldn't describe it as being unusual in anyway. Clearly, a lot of people and retailers everywhere thought Toy Story 3 would be a great toy movie. And the good news is, it's turned out to be a great toy movie. But I don't think their pacing wa
componenttext: No, J.T., I wouldn't describe it as being unusual in anyway. Clearly, a lot of people and retailers everywhere thought Toy Story 3 would be a great toy movie. And the good news is, it's turned out to be a great toy movie. But I don't think their pacing was unusual.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, you bought back some shares in the quarter. I know there's been talk about buybacks versus dividend increases versus whatever in terms of maximizing shareholder value. Had there been any sort of reason, in-depth discussion studies, whatever that
componenttext: And then, you bought back some shares in the quarter. I know there's been talk about buybacks versus dividend increases versus whatever in terms of maximizing shareholder value. Had there been any sort of reason, in-depth discussion studies, whatever that might help you figure out which way to lean on that? Because it seems like the share buybacks, while they've done a good job in decreasing the share base, say, over a period of time, they haven't been that effective. So maybe any update on that?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Not particularly. As I have mentioned, I believe or Kevin may have mentioned last quarter, this was a Board level decision. And the Board has, continues to be actively engaged into discussions. Particularly after last year, when you recall that given the
componenttext: Not particularly. As I have mentioned, I believe or Kevin may have mentioned last quarter, this was a Board level decision. And the Board has, continues to be actively engaged into discussions. Particularly after last year, when you recall that given the macro environment, we are sort of in hunkered-down mode. We said our priorities last year were going to be for having a stronger balance sheet, increasing cash, reducing debt and we also wanted to protect the dividend. We did all of that. We improved our credit metrics and improved our credit ratings. And so this year, we reengaged in discussions at the Board level. Reaffirmed the capital investment framework that I think we went public with in early 2003 or thereabouts, Kevin?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And so, Kevin and the Board and the rest of us continue to look at what's the highest and best use of capital in our judgment at any given point in time. And we also talked to investors about their preference for dividends and share repurchases and what t
componenttext: And so, Kevin and the Board and the rest of us continue to look at what's the highest and best use of capital in our judgment at any given point in time. And we also talked to investors about their preference for dividends and share repurchases and what tax rates might -- what implications there might be from tax rates and those sorts of things. But from an overall, strategic, macro sort of basis, there's no real change in our strategy or approach.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess, that you stay consistent with that framework in the second quarter when we repurchased 5 million shares of our stock at a total cost of about $111 million. And as Bob said, we remained committed to core capital build, shareholder value, prett
componenttext: And I guess, that you stay consistent with that framework in the second quarter when we repurchased 5 million shares of our stock at a total cost of about $111 million. And as Bob said, we remained committed to core capital build, shareholder value, pretty much as we've done for the last 10 years.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then last question on the Chinese labor front. The contracts in place are pretty firm at this point in terms of allowing you to predict what your input costs are going to be on the labor side, or is there some variability there that you might have to
componenttext: And then last question on the Chinese labor front. The contracts in place are pretty firm at this point in terms of allowing you to predict what your input costs are going to be on the labor side, or is there some variability there that you might have to take some pricing list to protect margin from?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Just from the perspective of what's going on, I think as expected in 2010, China announced the minimum wage to grow about 20% in our key provinces effective May 1. And if you look at our 2010 pricing, we assumed the majority of this double-digit increase
componenttext: Just from the perspective of what's going on, I think as expected in 2010, China announced the minimum wage to grow about 20% in our key provinces effective May 1. And if you look at our 2010 pricing, we assumed the majority of this double-digit increase in wages. But we're keeping an eye on further roll out of wage increases in our key manufacturing provinces. That said, we continue to execute our Global Cost Leadership Program and other cost and manufacturing efficiency programs in 2010. But we price our products consistent with making progress against our long-term annual goal of 15% to 20% operating margins.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: We're, really, J.T., not looking at the additional price increases this year. We haven't yet priced next fall line. And given the labor costs, given oil, oil today is probably $75 versus $67 maybe a year ago. Given what's going on in the supply chain and
componenttext: We're, really, J.T., not looking at the additional price increases this year. We haven't yet priced next fall line. And given the labor costs, given oil, oil today is probably $75 versus $67 maybe a year ago. Given what's going on in the supply chain and costs and currencies and those sorts of things. It's more likely than that, that we will be pricing next year. And my current point of view is we'll probably be pricing more aggressively as we did in 2009 than we have in 2010. It's a next-year issue, not at this-year issue.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you give us any sense of the sentiment of major retailers in Europe in terms of their outlook and their willingness to sort of stock up for holiday? Yes, last year was a low-water point. I guess we're trying to find out what the new normal is
componenttext: And then can you give us any sense of the sentiment of major retailers in Europe in terms of their outlook and their willingness to sort of stock up for holiday? Yes, last year was a low-water point. I guess we're trying to find out what the new normal is. Could you give us any insight into what they're telling you?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd say in general, we've seen good momentum across the portfolio and around the globe. The business has actually done pretty well in markets like Italy, Portugal, Spain, Southern Europe. We continue to have a good quarter. I think we remain cauti
componenttext: I guess I'd say in general, we've seen good momentum across the portfolio and around the globe. The business has actually done pretty well in markets like Italy, Portugal, Spain, Southern Europe. We continue to have a good quarter. I think we remain cautious and conservative. Retailers remain cautious and conservative. My view is they're going to continue to be tight through this holiday season. Not surprising to us, and that was baked into our expectations for the year. But the business in general has held up pretty well, and I don't know whether or not we're yet at the new norm. But there's no real change in sentiment, Kevin, I'd say in the last three to six months.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Kelter from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Kelter from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess first, maybe you could just follow-on what you were just talking about with respect to the holiday season. When you said you thought that retailers might remain tight on inventory, were you referring to southern Europe or were you referring to mor
componenttext: I guess first, maybe you could just follow-on what you were just talking about with respect to the holiday season. When you said you thought that retailers might remain tight on inventory, were you referring to southern Europe or were you referring to more broadly all of Europe, United States, etc.?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm referring more broadly to all around the globe. Retailers continue to be tight on inventory, that's not surprising to us. I don't think they're going to broadly rebuild inventory anywhere around the world. I think that's just their view of the marketp
componenttext: I'm referring more broadly to all around the globe. Retailers continue to be tight on inventory, that's not surprising to us. I don't think they're going to broadly rebuild inventory anywhere around the world. I think that's just their view of the marketplace. It's consistent with our view of the marketplace. So similar to last year, people are going to be cautious, and they tend to buy what they're selling as opposed to buying a lot in advance of selling. If we look at -- the U.S. is our best data. If we look at retail inventories in the U.S., which we calculate from shipments and point-of-sale information that we receive from retailers, the inventories today, let me put it that way. The inventories today in the U.S. at retail are up maybe in the low to mid-single digits. But most of that, all of that's really due to the natural build for these entertainment properties that are very strong right now. If you exclude the entertainment properties, the retail inventories are down below year ago, and people are pretty tight with inventory last year. And so my view is that trend's going to continue this year. I don't think retailers anywhere, and I'm aware, are looking to rebuild inventories. And when the consumer buys it, we will buy more.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question I have is on gross margins. Well, I'm surprised that our guess is gross margins normally go up at least 100 basis points from first to second quarter on seasonality. And this time, they went down 100. And you mentioned a lot of that you
componenttext: The next question I have is on gross margins. Well, I'm surprised that our guess is gross margins normally go up at least 100 basis points from first to second quarter on seasonality. And this time, they went down 100. And you mentioned a lot of that you from higher royalties and from the entertainment properties. But the only thing new in the quarter was Toy Story, which should be less than 10% of sales. So is there anything else going on that why gross margins would have gone 200 basis points in difference than the normal seasonality in the business?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, I think we did improve by 290 basis points to 48.1% compared to last year. And as I said earlier, gross margin benefited from favorable product costs, price increases and savings from the Global Cost Leadership Program, partially offset by th
componenttext: Well, again, I think we did improve by 290 basis points to 48.1% compared to last year. And as I said earlier, gross margin benefited from favorable product costs, price increases and savings from the Global Cost Leadership Program, partially offset by the mix due to higher royalties related to our new entertainment properties. I think your focus on the royalties are correct this quarter versus the first quarter, and that we did see more entertainment license property sales in the second quarter. But also this quarter, we continued to benefit from lower commodity costs that occurred last year. We were buying inputs and manufacturing to our 2010 spring line relative to the near record high input cost that we experienced in late 2008, when we were purchasing inputs for manufacture of our spring 2009 product line. In our 2010 first launch, it also improved due to the continuous improvement programs like our Global Cost Leadership Program, and other manufacturing programs across our supply chain. So I think we made good progress again to rebuilding our gross margins and our goals to sustain gross margins consistent with our long-term goal. I think again, royalties was part of that. I think also cycling through the commodity costs as we were building 2010 product, those commodity costs got more expensive as we moved from the first quarter to the second quarter.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly on the capital structure, debt, share repurchases, et cetera. You said you had $250 million coming due. Is there any reason why you wouldn't refinance that amount or do you plan on paying it down? And then even beyond that, maybe, have you
componenttext: And then lastly on the capital structure, debt, share repurchases, et cetera. You said you had $250 million coming due. Is there any reason why you wouldn't refinance that amount or do you plan on paying it down? And then even beyond that, maybe, have you considered refinancing for a greater amount and taking on a more aggressive capital structure and deploying cash back to shareholders?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say overall, it's a little early to have those discussions. As Kevin always talks about, this is a Board level decision and we review of those things with the Board, and then try and use capital as best we can at the time. So I just would go back to t
componenttext: I'd say overall, it's a little early to have those discussions. As Kevin always talks about, this is a Board level decision and we review of those things with the Board, and then try and use capital as best we can at the time. So I just would go back to the capital and investment framework, which we've articulated publicly. And there's no reason to believe we're going to come off of that set of guidelines.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think the important things in those guidelines supporting our credit metrics and credit ratings, and I think that's key to having year-end cash of $800 million to $1 billion target and a debt to total capital ratio of around 25%. So I don't see
componenttext: Yes, and I think the important things in those guidelines supporting our credit metrics and credit ratings, and I think that's key to having year-end cash of $800 million to $1 billion target and a debt to total capital ratio of around 25%. So I don't see that changing.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Hayley Wolff from Rochdale Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Hayley Wolff from Rochdale Securities.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, you and I think, David Stockton (sic) [Bryan Stockton] have been quoted in some publications as being fairly upbeat about the holiday period. Can you elaborate on that?
componenttext: Bob, you and I think, David Stockton (sic) [Bryan Stockton] have been quoted in some publications as being fairly upbeat about the holiday period. Can you elaborate on that?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in general, if you look at what we all thought in the industry a year ago, we were all fairly pessimistic. We had come off a tough Christmas in 2008 when the global economy tanked, and retailers and manufacturers like us were all anxious abo
componenttext: Well, I think in general, if you look at what we all thought in the industry a year ago, we were all fairly pessimistic. We had come off a tough Christmas in 2008 when the global economy tanked, and retailers and manufacturers like us were all anxious about what the holidays look like in 2009. We were pretty cautious about inventories when we went into 2009. Retailers were quite cautious about inventories. The good news is the market cleared. Everybody did well. Products sold and holidays were good. So if you fast-forward now, our view of the world this year is, okay, from a POS and consumer standpoint, we're hopeful the worst is behind us. So we don't have that pessimism that we had a year ago at this time. That being said, I don't think anybody thinks we're back to good growth in the macro economy. And I don't think anybody's building inventories in anticipation of renewed consumer spending. So I think we're going to continue with sentiments that we probably had for the last six or eight months.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: So as we go through this current slowdown, do you have internally any need to reset expectations? Are retailers more conservative, maybe pushing back a little bit?
componenttext: So as we go through this current slowdown, do you have internally any need to reset expectations? Are retailers more conservative, maybe pushing back a little bit?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say retailers would continue to be conservative. I wouldn't describe them broadly as more conservative. I think if you look at how we calculate their inventories, they've been tight with toys for some period of time now. And I really don't expect
componenttext: No, I'd say retailers would continue to be conservative. I wouldn't describe them broadly as more conservative. I think if you look at how we calculate their inventories, they've been tight with toys for some period of time now. And I really don't expect that to change much one way or the other. A lot of retailers saw the market clear pretty quickly last year, and I'm sure they're hopeful to continue that again this year. They're not going to get ahead of themselves.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in the Other Girls segment, how much longer do we have tough comps of High School Musical and the Hannah Montana? And then regarding Polly Pocket, I know there's been a relaunch or retooling. What's been the response to that and do we think Polly
componenttext: And then in the Other Girls segment, how much longer do we have tough comps of High School Musical and the Hannah Montana? And then regarding Polly Pocket, I know there's been a relaunch or retooling. What's been the response to that and do we think Polly can turnaround?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're about done with some of the older Disney properties that we cycled through. Polly has shown pretty good momentum of late here in the U.S. but it's early. So we'll have to see how the holiday season goes. We still have opportunities to do a b
componenttext: I think we're about done with some of the older Disney properties that we cycled through. Polly has shown pretty good momentum of late here in the U.S. but it's early. So we'll have to see how the holiday season goes. We still have opportunities to do a better job overseas with Polly.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then last question. On the legal expenses, so you're now building up with the expectation of going to trial on phase 2 of the Bratz. So as we think about, I know you don't like to give any guidance, but as we think about legal as getting in the way of
componenttext: And then last question. On the legal expenses, so you're now building up with the expectation of going to trial on phase 2 of the Bratz. So as we think about, I know you don't like to give any guidance, but as we think about legal as getting in the way of any kind of SG&A improvement, how should we think about the legal expenses going forward?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that probably the only thing I can give you is look back at history when in full year quarter in 2008, we incurred legal incremental litigation fees related to primarily the MGA trial, which incurred in May through July of 2008. It was incremental
componenttext: I think that probably the only thing I can give you is look back at history when in full year quarter in 2008, we incurred legal incremental litigation fees related to primarily the MGA trial, which incurred in May through July of 2008. It was incremental legal cost of about $37 million. For 2009, when we weren't in trial and weren't preparing for trial, litigation-related legal costs decreased by $33 million and that's primarily related to MGA. So that's probably the guidance I can give you. And while we reduced expenses in 2009, we'll continue to make the appropriate level of investments in legal fees until the legal matters are resolved.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Margaret Whitfield from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Margaret Whitfield from Sterne Agee.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: If you could comment on how your inventories are overseas relative to point-of-sale, Bob? Also, I wondered, I've seen a few holiday lines propping up at retail as well as few SKUs for Monster High adjusted. If you could give us your thoughts on the early
componenttext: If you could comment on how your inventories are overseas relative to point-of-sale, Bob? Also, I wondered, I've seen a few holiday lines propping up at retail as well as few SKUs for Monster High adjusted. If you could give us your thoughts on the early read there? And finally, two small questions. When will the Toy Story 3 DVD debut and what was the ForEx impact to the bottom line in Q2?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start, Margaret, with inventories overseas. The data isn't as good as it is in the U.S. But broadly speaking, I'd say, the trend is consistent. So we're not going through numbers. I'd say, in general, retailers remain tight with inventories. We're
componenttext: Let me start, Margaret, with inventories overseas. The data isn't as good as it is in the U.S. But broadly speaking, I'd say, the trend is consistent. So we're not going through numbers. I'd say, in general, retailers remain tight with inventories. We're certainly tight with credit, continue to be tight with credit. And I don't think that the United States is being typical of what's going on around the world in terms of retail trends. I haven't yet seen Monster High adjusted, so you're ahead of me. Frankly, I haven't seen Monster High toys on the shelves either. So you're ahead of me. I have been out looking for them. It's too early. But clearly, we've got high expectations for Monster High at least in terms of starting to build a franchise, which we're committed to do. So the Justice program is appearing now. I've heard the toys are starting to appear but I haven't seen any. And in general, I think that some of the fall toys coming out of either Mattel or some of our other competitors are starting to appear at retail. And my sense is based on sort of the POS over the last several weeks. Things are off to pretty good start. I think an answer to your question on the Toy Story 3 DVD, my recollection is it comes out around Thanksgiving or sometime in the November time period in time for the holiday season.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And on your final question on ForEx. ForEx was a negative three percentage point impact in worldwide gross sales for the quarter. It had no impact on EPS for the quarter as well as for the first half.
componenttext: And on your final question on ForEx. ForEx was a negative three percentage point impact in worldwide gross sales for the quarter. It had no impact on EPS for the quarter as well as for the first half.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Bob, if you had any more specifics on the holiday toys. Sing-A-Ma-Jigs or the Video Cam Barbie or anything else that's out in terms of the early read, along with the Barbie entertainment line for Q4?
componenttext: I was wondering, Bob, if you had any more specifics on the holiday toys. Sing-A-Ma-Jigs or the Video Cam Barbie or anything else that's out in terms of the early read, along with the Barbie entertainment line for Q4?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: It's very early, Margaret. Things that you have seen, I haven't yet seen on the shelves and I go to retailers every weekend at this time frame of year. So I'd say it's too early to get excited one way or the other. But we've got good momentum. Retailers a
componenttext: It's very early, Margaret. Things that you have seen, I haven't yet seen on the shelves and I go to retailers every weekend at this time frame of year. So I'd say it's too early to get excited one way or the other. But we've got good momentum. Retailers are supportive of some of these key lines that you've mentioned like Sing-A-Ma-Jigs or like Video Girl Barbie. I've heard they're selling, but I wouldn't get excited one way or the other. If you just look at the absolute number of pieces that are out there, it's just not material yet.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Felicia Hendrix from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Felicia Hendrix from Barclays Capital.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, just back on the SG&A, you had said obviously, usually the incentive accruals happen more in the second half of the year but because of accounting, may move somewhere in the second quarter. Does that mean that if the timing of incentive accruals ar
componenttext: Kevin, just back on the SG&A, you had said obviously, usually the incentive accruals happen more in the second half of the year but because of accounting, may move somewhere in the second quarter. Does that mean that if the timing of incentive accruals are changed for the whole year, should we expect less in the second half?

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's going to depend upon our performance in the second half. But again, the majority of the incentive accrual occurs in the second half of the year, and it's been reasonably split between the third and fourth quarters based upon history.
componenttext: I think that's going to depend upon our performance in the second half. But again, the majority of the incentive accrual occurs in the second half of the year, and it's been reasonably split between the third and fourth quarters based upon history.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: So there's nothing really like a material pull-forward into the second quarter? That's what I was trying to figure out.
componenttext: So there's nothing really like a material pull-forward into the second quarter? That's what I was trying to figure out.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Wal-Mart have seen some leadership changes. I'm just wondering, it might be too early. But if you're seeing any changes there, in particular with how they're assigning shelf space to things like toys and other items.
componenttext: And then Wal-Mart have seen some leadership changes. I'm just wondering, it might be too early. But if you're seeing any changes there, in particular with how they're assigning shelf space to things like toys and other items.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't seen any change at all. There hasn't been any impact on the folks who work in the toy business. And I'm not aware of any change in strategy broadly because of the change in leadership.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: In general, Felicia, from a POS standpoint as we talked for probably the last eight months to a year, we are a little bit disappointed in the POS trends on the Fisher-Price last year. We think a lot of that was driven by price points on key drivers, which
componenttext: In general, Felicia, from a POS standpoint as we talked for probably the last eight months to a year, we are a little bit disappointed in the POS trends on the Fisher-Price last year. We think a lot of that was driven by price points on key drivers, which we rectified this year. Some of those products are just starting to sell right now. I did see iXL, for example. I did find one of our products out there. I saw iXL the other day. So I think in general, Fisher-Price, if you go back over the last 10 years, it's probably been the best performing major brand in the toy industry. Certainly one of the best. Fisher-Price is a terrific franchise. But from a core product standpoint, we've been a little disappointed in the POS. Fortunately, if you look at recent weeks, the momentum is improving a bit. We're also hampered in that segment by things like Power Wheels, which is a very large expensive item. So it's disproportionate because of the retail dollars involved. And Power Wheels has not done particularly well since the economy started to contract.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: So those reasons just seem kind of fundamental to your specific business in general. I'm wondering if you're seeing any kind of uptick competitively as well.
componenttext: So those reasons just seem kind of fundamental to your specific business in general. I'm wondering if you're seeing any kind of uptick competitively as well.

headline: Mattel Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's always competition. Certainly, the  infant/preschool category over the decade, I've been looking at the numbers, it's been a growth category within the Toy business. Fisher-Price has led that growth, has gained share more times than that in
componenttext: Well, there's always competition. Certainly, the  infant/preschool category over the decade, I've been looking at the numbers, it's been a growth category within the Toy business. Fisher-Price has led that growth, has gained share more times than that in the 10 years I've been looking at the data. It is a competitive category. We do see new competitors coming in all the time, but Fisher-Price has held its own and continues to hold its own and just continuing to build share as we speak.
